p.hi: Woundes in the bought of the arme are dangerous, becauſe of the great veynes.

div.p: Cubiti ſuſpecti propter ſpaſmum & inflamationes.

p.hi: Woundes are to be ſuſpected in the Cubite, becauſe of the Crampe and inflamation.

div.p: Ex bile flaua & ſanguine nati tumores, nunquam dolore deſtituuntur.

p.hi: Tumors of yellow choller and bloud, are euer full of paine.

div.p: Cancer in pectore vel collo aegrè ve • nunquam curatur.Cancer in pectore vel collo.

p.hi: A Canker in the breaſt or necke is hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: Cancro vel veteribus vlceribus immundo corpore incidentibusAcuta medicamina. acuta medicamina adhibita ſemper nociua.

p.hi: Sharpe medecines applyed to Canckers or old vlcers in an vncleane bodie, do alwayes hurt.

div.p: Cancer qui in propatulo graſſatur non facile ſaluti conſentit.Cancer qui in propatulo graſſatur.

p.hi: A Canker that eateth outwardly, is hardly cured.

div.p: Cancer non vlceratus atque iam confirmatus curationemCancer non vlceratus. non admittit, niſi radicitus extirpetur, aut per ſectionem, aut per vſtionem.

p.hi: A Cancer not vlcerated, and thorougly confirmed, can not be cured, except it be wholy remoued either by inciſion, or cauterization.

div.p: Cancer vlceratus qui eſt in venis, neruis & oſsibus difficulterCancer vlceratus. curatur.

p.hi: An vlcerated Canker in the veynes, ſinewes and bones, is hardly cured.

div.p: Cancer antiquatus incurabilis exiſtit.Cancer anti quatus.

p.hi: An old Canker is vncurable.

div.p: In canis rabioſi morſu peſsimum eſt ſignum & mortaleCanis rabidi morſus. permixtio rationis & abhominatio aquae mundae.

p.hi: In the biting of a madde dogge, it is an euill and deadly ſigne to raue and abhorre fayre water.

div.p: Canis rabidi morſus quadraginta dierum ſpatio recluſus foret.

p.hi: The biting of a madde dogge ſhould be kept open the ſpace of fortie dayes.

div.p: Carbunculus minus lethalis eſt primùm ruber, deindeCarbunc • l • s. citrinus apparēs, qui vero liueſcit aut nigricatiugular.

p.hi: That Carbuncle is leſſe deadly, which is firſt redde, and after yellow, but that which w • xeth ſwarty or blacke, is paſt all helpe.

div.p: Calida ſuppurationem faciunt, cutem emolliunt, extenuant,Calid • . dolorem leniunt in ſpaſmo, diſtentione & oſſibus fractis.

p.hi: Hote things do ripen, mollifie the ſkinne, extenuate, and aſſwage payne in crampes, crickes, and broken bones.

div.p: Calor gignit carnis effaeminationem, neruorum incontinētiam,Calor. mentis ſtuporem, h • morragiam, lipothimiam.

p.hi: Heate cauſeth neſhneſſe of the fleſh, ſhaking and trembling of
the ſinewes, dumpiſhnes of the minde, iſſue of bloud, and ſounding.

div.p: Carnis ſupercreſcentis cauſa eſt humiditas, & mala abſtertio.

p.hi: The cauſe of ſuperfluous or prowde fleſh, is too much moyſture, and want of mundification.

div.p: Corpora exercitata, morbis minus obnoxia eſſe ſolent.

p.hi: Thoſe bodies yt are exerciſed, are leaſt annoyes with diſeaſes.

div.p: Ex intemperie calida citius quam ex frigida aegri intereunt, ob ignis in agendo celerem efficaciam.

p.hi: Men dye of a hoate diſtemperature ſooner then of a colde, becauſe of the ſwift force of fire in working.

div.head: D.
div.p:
DIſlocatio groſsis, pinguibus, & teneris, contingen •
Diſlocatio in groſsis, pinguibus & teneris corporibus. corporibus aegrè ſanatur.

p.hi: Diſlocations in groſſe, fat, and tender bodies, are hard to be cured.

div.p: Iuncta cum apoſtemate diſlocatio difficulter curatur.Diſlocatio cum apoſtemate▪ Diſlocatio cum fractura.

p.hi: A diſlocation with an impoſtume is hard to be cured.

div.p: Diſlocatio cum adherente fractura difficulter curatur.

p.hi: A Diſlocation with a fracture is hardly cured.

div.p: Si coxa excidit, mucores ibi naſcuntur, crus contabeſcitCoxae diſlocatio. & claudicat.

p.hi: If the hippe be diſlocated, there gathereth in the place watr • ſh matter, and the thigh withereth away, and halteth.

div.p: Quaedam iuncturae ſunt facilis diſlocationis vt genu.Iuncturarum diſlocatio. quaedam difficilis vt digitorum & cubiti: quaedam medio modo, vt coxae & ſcapulae.

p.hi: Some ioynts are eaſy to be diſlocated, as the knée: ſome hard, as the fingers and cubite, and ſome indifferent, as the hippe, and ſhoulderblades.

div.p: Quae facilis ſunt diſlocationis faciliter reſtaurantur: quae difficilis difficulter: quae medio modo, mediocriter.

p.hi: Thoſe ioynts which are eaſie to be diſlocated, are eaſie to b • e reſtored▪ thoſe which are hard, hardly: and thoſe which are indifferent, indifferently.

div.p:
Diſlocatio illa eſt deterior quae eſt cum ligamenti fractura,D ••• ocatio cum ligam ••
ti 〈…〉 . qua os cum oſse coniungitur & alligatur, & vt plurimum fit in capite anchae & ſpatulae.

p.hi: That diſlocation is the worſt which commeth with the fracture of a ligament, whereby one bone ioyneth with another, and for the moſt part it chaunceth in the head of the ſhoulder blade and hippe.

div.p: Quando iunctura ad omnes partes poſitionis ſine difficultateIunctura non diſlocata neque ſeparata eſſe cognoſcitur. mouetur, non eſt diſlocata, neque ſeparata.

p.hi: When the ioynt without difficultie may be mo • ed euery way, it is neither diſlocated nor halfe put forth.

div.p: Mandibula quando ad interiora diſlocatur, os remanetMandibulae diſlocatio ad interiora. apertum: & dentes inferioris mandibulae poſteriores ſunt dentibus mandibulae ſuperioris.

p.hi: When the iawe is diſlocated inwardly, the mouth remaineth open, and the teeth of the nether iawe ſtand more backward than they of the vpper.

div.p:
Quando autem ad exteriora diſlocatur, clauditur os, & a
••• iriAd exteriora. no • poteſt: apparet imminentia mandibulae ad extra, & priuatur loquela.

p.hi: But when it is diſlocated outwardly, the mouth is ſhut and cannot bee opened, and there appeareth a part of the • awe ſticking out, and ſpeach is taken away.

div.p:
Diſlocatio humeri quandoque fit ad inferiora, & • entiturDiſlocatio •
▪ me • i. ſub axillo in tactu capitis▪ vert • b • i, ac ſi eſſet ouum, & in parte ſuperiori concauitas que tactu facile comprehenditur.

p.hi: The ſhoulder ſometime is diſlocated towards the inferiour part thereof, which may be 〈◊〉 vnder the ar • ehole, as if it were an Egge, and in the vpper part is a cauitie, which by touching is eaſely perceiued.

div.p:
Ancha, ſi diſlocatur ad anteriora, tunc pes eſt longior, &Anchae diſlocatio ad ante
• iora. & non eſt poſsibile plicare pedem, niſi cum dolore, & non poteſt ambulare niſi ſuper calcaneum, & multoties apoſtematur inguen, & retinetur vrina.

p.hi: If the hippe be diſlocated towards the forepart, then the foote is longer, and it is not poſſible to bowe the foote without paine, and the partie cannot goe about vpon the heele, and oftimes the flancke doth impoſtumate, and the vrine ſtoppeth.

div.p: Quando fit diſlocatio ad interiora tunc pes diſlocatusAd interiora. redditur longior, quoad viſum, altero, & genu eminentius, & non poteſt duplicare pedem ſuum apud inguen inflatum & apoſtematum, quoniam caput coxae iam introiuit in ipſum.

p.hi: When the hippe is diſlocated inwardly, then the legge on that ſide ſeemeth longer than the other, and the knee more eminent, and he cannot double his legge to his flancke being puffed vp and impoſtumated, becauſe the head of the hippe hath entred into it.

div.p: Si diſlocatur ad exteriora, abbreuiatur pes, apparet in inguineAd exteriora. profunditas & in eius oppoſito eminentia, inflatio in poſterioribus, & gen • ad interiora ſubuerſum.

p.hi: If the hippe bee diſlocated onewardly, the foote is ſhortned, there appeareth in the flancke a hollowneſſe, and ouer againſt it a part ſtanding out, a ſwelling in the hinder parts, and the knēe bowing inwards.

div.p: Cubitus diſlocatus retrorſum diſtendi minime poteſt, intror • umCubi • i diſlocatio introrſ •• . pl • cari nequit.

p.hi: If the cubite be diſlocated backwards, it cannot bee ſtretched out: if inward, it cannot be bowed.

div.p: Dextrorſum vero aut ſiniſtrorſum diſlocatum, forma iuncturaeDextrorſum a •• ſiniſtrorſum. & modus poſsibilitatis motionis oſtendit.

p.hi: But if the cubite bee diſlocated either to the right or left ſide, that is eaſely knowne by the forme of the ioynt, and the poſſibilitie of the motion.

div.p: Si pulſus brachij in cubito diſlocati tangatur, tangenti venaPulſus b • achij. diuiſa ſentitur.

p.hi: If you touch the pulſe of the arme that is diſlocated in the cubite, it ſeemeth as though it were a veyne diuided.

div.p:
Manus diſlocatus introrſum, digitos flectere nequit, cumManus di •• oc • tu • int • orſum & e • t • o •
ſ • m. extrorſum diſlocatur, digitos non poteſt extendere.

p.hi: When the hande is diſlocated inwardly, the fingers cannot bowe, when it is diſlocated outwardly the fingers cannot extend.

div.p: Mandibuloe diſlocatio ſi celeriter ſuppeditetur & ſymptomatibusMandibuloe diſlocatio. deſtituatur, in duodecim diebus curatur, ſed ſi ſymptomatibus coniuncta ſit, periculoſa fit.

p.hi: A diſlocation in the iawe is fully cured in twelue daies, if it be taken ſpeedily in hand and voyde of accidents: but if any accidents doe happen, it is daungerous.

div.p: Vertebrae ſi diſlocantur, ſemper periculoſum, ſaepe lethaleVertebr • r • m diſlocatio. eſt.

p.hi: A diſlocation in any of the vertebres, is alwaies and for the moſt part deadly.

div.p: Humeri diſlocatio in xx. diebus reſtauratur.Humeri diſlocatio.

p.hi: A diſlocation in the ſhoulder bones is reſtored in xx. daies.

div.p: Digiti diſlocati in xij. diebus curantur.Digiti diſlocatio.

p.hi: A diſlocation in the fingers is reſtored in xii. daies.

div.p: Coxa diſlocata in xxx. diebus reſtituitur.Coxa diſlocata.

p.hi: Diſlocations in the hippe are reſtored in xxx. daies.

div.p: In calce, tarſo, & pedum digitis, diſlocatio non penitusIn calce tarſo & pedum digitis diſlocatio. donec xl. dies praetereant, firmatur.

p.hi: A diſlocation in the heele, inſteppe and toes, is not reſtored in ſuch ſorte as the patient may goe vpon it, vntill xl. daies be ended.

div.p: Dolor à quatuor cauſis mouetur, viz. ab inciſione, eroſioneDolor. membri, alicuius fractura, & diſtentione; vt in apoſtemate.

p.hi: The cauſes of paine are foure, as inciſion, corroſion, breaking
of ſome member, and diſtention as by impoſtumation.

div.head: E
div.p: AB eryſipelate putredo & ſuppuratio malum.Putredo aut ſuppuratio ab eryſipelate.
Putrefaction and ſuppuration comming of Eryſipelas, is euill.
Ab exterioribus ſi vertitur ad interiora malum, ab interioribus autem ad exteriora, bonum.
If Eryſipelas doe goe from the outer to the inner parts, it is euill, but contrariwiſe it is good.
Eryſipelas exquiſitum raro terminatur ſuppuratione, ſedEryſipelas exquiſitum. magna ex parte inſenſibili tranſpiratione, ſeu reſolutione.
A perfect Eryſipilas is ſeldome cured by ſuppuration, but for the moſt parts by inſenſible tranſpiration, and reſolution.
Eryſipelata circa caput, curatu ſunt difficillima, ad • oqueEryſipelas circa caput. periculoſa eſſe ſolent; vt niſi efficax conſequatur auxilium, interdum affectos ſtrangulent.
Eryſipelas about the head is hard to be cured, and it is ſo daū gerous, that if it bee not ſpeedily helped with moſt excellent medicines, it ſometime ch • keth the patient.
Symptoma pra •• m eſt, ſi oſſe nudato ca • o circu • ſtans ab Eryſipelate occupari videatur.
The bone being bare, if Eryſipilas be in the fleſh round about, it is a very euill accident.
In curatione eryſepelatis quatuor ſcopis eſt vtendum.Eryſipelatis curatione ſcopi quatuor.

p.hi: In the curing of eryſipelas, there are foure rules to be obſerued▪

div.p: Primus ſcopus conſiſtit in vitae recta inſtitutione, atque victus rationis obſeruatione.

p.hi: The firſt rule conſiſteth in the right ordering of life, and obſeruing of diet.

div.p: Secundus, humoris ad partem affectam cōfluentis (quem antecedentem materiam appellant) auerſionem conſiderat.

p.hi: The ſecond conſiſteth in the turning away of the humor flowing to the affected part (which they call the antecedent matter.)

div.p: Tertius in humoris, qui iam in partem aegram influxit, (quem materiam coniunctam dicunt) vacuatione conſiſtit:

p.hi: The third conſiſteth in the euacuation of the humor, which hath alreadie flowed 〈◊〉 the affected part (called the matter conioyned.)

div.p:
Quartus circam ſymptomatum correctionem, ac propu •
ſionem verſatur.

p.hi: The fourth conſiſteth in the correction and expulſion of accidents.

div.head: F.
div.p: FIſtula eſt vlcus concauum, ſordidum, latum inferi •• s,Fiſtula▪ & ſtrictum exterius, quod modò clauditur & modò aperitur.

p.hi: A fiſtula is a hollow and filthy vlcer, broade within, and narrow without, which ſometime ſhutteth, and ſometime openeth.

div.p: In pulmonibus fiſtulae aegrè vel nunquam curantur.In pulmonibus.

p.hi: Fiſtulaes in the lungs, are hard or neuer cured.

div.p: In ſtomacho, inteſtinis, & veſica aegrè vel nunquam curanturIn ſtomacho inteſtinis & veſica. fiſtulae.

p.hi: Fiſtulaes in the ſtomacke, ſmall guttes and bladder, are hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: In oculis, faucibus, ventre, ſede, & iuncturis aegrè ſananturIn oculis, faucibus, ventre, ſede & inncturis. fiſtulae.

p.hi: Fiſtulaes in the eyes, iawes, belly, fundament, and ioynts, are hard to be cured.

div.p:
Fiſtulae in partibus carnoſis procul dubio curantur, tametſiPartibus carnoſ ••
foramina multa appareant.

p.hi: Fiſtulaes in fleſhy partes are vndoubtedly to be cured, although many holes do appeare.

div.p: Fiſtula lachrymalis eſt difficilis curationis propter oculiFiſtula lachrymalis. propinquitatem & ſenſibilitatem, & inueterata, vix curatur, ob magnam carnis duritiem.

p.hi: The lachrimall fiſtulae is hard to be cured, by reaſon of the vicinitie and ſenſibility of the eye, and being old, it is ſcarſely euer cured, by reaſon of the great hardneſſe of the fleſh.

div.p: Si fiſtula fuerit in carne, ſanies eſt alba, ſi in oſſe, eſt ſicutIn carne, oſſe, & neruo. lotura carnis, ſi in neruo, eſt nigri coloris.

p.hi: If the fiſtulae be in the fleſh, the matter is white, if it be in the bone, it is like waſhing of▪fleſh, if in the ſinew, it is black in colour.

div.p:
Si ad os, vel cartilaginem, vel neruum, vel muſculos, velIn oſſe, cartilagine, neruo, muſculis, thorace, vulua grandibus ve
• is & arterijs. thoracem, vel vuluam, vel ad grandes venas, arteriaſque penetrauerit: ſemper periculoſum, ſaepè peſti • erum eſt.

p.hi: If a fiſtulae pearce either to the bone, cartilage, ſinewe, muſcles, matrice, or ſmall • eyues and arteries, it is alwayes dangerous, oftentimes peſtiferous.

div.p: Si fiſtula fuerit in aliquo loco cuius ſinus penetrat ad oculos, vt iuxta naſum, incurabilis eſt, quia nec inciſionem, nec aliquam medicinam ibi adminiſtra • e poſſumus, propter teneram ſubſtantiam oculorum.

p.hi: A fiſtulae in any place that hath his paſſage to the eyes, as beſide the noſe, is vncurable, becauſe we can neither make inciſion, nor miniſter thereto any medicine, by reaſon of the tender ſubſtance of the eyes.

div.head: De fracturis oſſium. F.
div.p: FRactura cranij magna, aegrè perſanatur.Cranij fractura.

p.hi: A great fracture in the ſkull is hard to be cured.

div.p:
In fractura cranij febris acuta, ſpaſmus, tremor, alienatioSigna mortalia in fractura cranij. mentis, ſyncope, vocis abſciſio, rubedo, & tenebroſitas oculorum, timoroſa & mortalia ſigna, praecipue ſi
maneant & non remittantur.

p.hi: A ſharpe feuer, crampe, trembling, alienation of the minde, ſounding, loſſe of ſpeach, redneſſe and darkeneſſe of the eyes, are fearefull and deadly ſignes in a fracture of the ſkull, eſpecially if they remayne ſtill, and vaniſh not.

div.p: Denigratio durae matris quae non mundificatur cumDurae matris deuigratio. melle, ſignificat mortem.
If the blacknes of Dura mater cannot be mundified with hony, it is death.
Tumor magnus in fractura cranij, praecipue ſi citò euanueritTumor magnus in fractura cranij. ſine cauſa rationabili, malum.

p.hi: A great tumor in the fracture of the ſkull is euill, eſpecially if it vaniſh ſoone away without a reaſonable cauſe.

div.p: Tumor paruus & ſaniei bona digeſtio, bonum.Tumor paruus.

p.hi: A ſmall tumor with a good digeſtion of the matter is good.

div.p: Caro rubra in conſolidatione cranij, bonum.Caro rubra.

p.hi: Red fleſh in the conſolidation of the ſkull is good.

div.p: Signa cranij fracti ſunt, contuſio magna, ſeparatio cutisSigna cranij fracta. ab oſsibus, apoplexia, vertigo, vocis deſtructio, ſonus rancus percuſſo capite cum virga, ſtridor dentium filum retinentium dum perc • titur filum, humiditas per fiſ • uram pullulans retento anhelitus.

p.hi: The ſignes of the ſkull being broken, are theſe, a great contuſion, a ſeparating of the ſkinne from the bone, apoplery; giddineſſe, deſtruction of the voyce, a hoarſe ſound being ſtricken with a rodde vpon the head, g •• ſhing of the teeth▪ holding a thred betwixt them when the threed is ſtricken, moyſture comming out by the ri • t when the breath is holden.

div.p: Craneo fracto patiens ſe multas candelas videre putat, ſaepe niſi ſuſtineatur cadit, non v •• ro intuetur lucem, neque pannum diſ •• r •• fu ••• rt.

p.hi: The ſkull being broken, the patient thinketh that he ſeeth many candles, he falleth often if 〈◊〉 not holden, he cannot
endure to behold the light, neyther can he ſuffer a cloth to be torne.

div.p: Sanguis ſi inter cranium & meningem inciderit ad putredinemSanguis inter cranium & meningem. vertit, nec non ſymptomata nociua adfert.

p.hi: If bloud fall betweene the ſkull and hard membrane, it will turne to putrefaction, and bring euill accidents.

div.p: Sanguis ſi fluxerit per nares, aures vel os, poſt caſum, velSigna partium inteſtinorum laeſionis. ictum, laeſam eſſe aliquam partem internam neceſſe eſt, quanquam fractura vel oſsis depreſsio extra non appareat.

p.hi: If bloud iſſue foorthby the noſtrilles, cares, or mouth, after a fall or ſtroake, it muſt needes be that ſome inward part be hurt, although the fracture or depreſſion of the bone appeare not outwardly.

div.p: Fractura cranij in plenilunio eſt verenda.

p.hi: A fracture of the ſkull in the full of the moone is to be feared.

div.p: In fractura cranij, terminus ad centum dies, vel ſecundum alios, ad 46.

p.hi: A fracture in the ſkull is cured in a hundred dayes, or as ſome ſay in 46.

div.p: Cubitus firmatur plurimum diebus. 30.Cubid fractura.

p.hi: A fracture in the cubit is for the moſt part cured in thirtie dayes.

div.p: Brachium & tibia ſi ritè curentur diebus circiter 40. occaleſcunt.Brachium & Tibia.

p.hi: Fractures in the arme or legge, if they be rightly cured, are confirmed in 40. dayes.

div.p: Coſta poſt vnum & vigeſimum diem ferrumen implet.Coſta.

p.hi: A fracture in a ribbe, is in 21. dayes ſouldred.

div.p: Corporibus macilentis fracturae perbellè ſanantur.Corporibus macilentis fracturae. Floreſcente inuentute fracturae.

p.hi: Fractures in leane bodies are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Floreſcente iuuentute fracturae modico negotio curātur.

p.hi: Fractures in flouriſhing youth are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Quaecunque fracturae ijs inſunt corporibus quibus requiesCorporibus requiem habentibus. benigna conceditur facilè admittunt curationem.

p.hi: Fractures in thoſe bodies that may reſt, are eaſie to be cured.

div.p: Fracturaeomnes iuncturis vicinae aegrè ſolidantur.Circa iuncturas.

p.hi: A fracture neere the ioynt is hart to be cured.

div.p: Os fruſtatim comminutum difficilè coaleſcit.Os fruſtatim cōminutum.

p.hi: A bone broken all to ſhiuers is hardly cured.

div.p: Os in naribus perfractum decem dierum ſpatio conſolideſcit.Narium fractura.

p.hi: A fracture in the noſtrilles doth conſolidate within the ſpace of tenne daies.

div.p: Fractura quae cum dolore, vel inflammatione, aut carnisCum dolore inflāmatione, aut carnis contuſione. contuſione incidit mala eſt.

p.hi: A fracture with payne, inflāmation or confuſion of the fleſh, is euill.

div.p: Fractura in decrepitis & cholericis, ac ijs viciſsim qui ſeròIn decrepitis & cholericis. aegrotabunt, cura longa commoratur.

p.hi: Fractures in olde and cholericke perſons, and thoſe eſpecially which are ſicke towards night, are hard to be cured.

div.p: Fractura per longum interuallum non reſtituta aegrè curatur.Fractura inueterata.

p.hi: A fracture long vnreſtored, is hardly after cured.

div.p: Fractura tranſuerſim os ſecans, perfacilis curationis.Tranſuerſim os ſecans.

p.hi: A fracture ouerthwart the bone is eaſie of curation.

div.p: Fractura ſymptomatis priuata facilè curatur.Symptomatis priuaca.

p.hi: A fracture without accidents, is eaſie to be cured.

div.p: Fere intra 14. & 21. diem ſaneſcunt, maxilla, iugulum, ſcapula,Maxilla, iugulum, ſcapula, os tali, calx, manus, & planta. os tali, calx, manus, planta.

p.hi: A fracture in the iawe, cannell bone, ſhoulder-blade, hecle, hande, and middle of the foote, is commonly cured within 14. or 21. daies.

div.p: Inter 27. & 40. diem humeri & foemora ſaneſcunt.Humeri & foemora.

p.hi: Fractures in the arme and thigh, are cured betweene 27. and 40. daies.

div.p: Coxa diebus quinquaginta coaleſcit.Coxa.

p.hi: The Hippe is reſtored in fiftie daies.

div.p: Pes ſexaginta dierum ſpatio, ſi quieſcat, conſaneſcat.Pes.

p.hi: A fracture in the foote, if it may haue reſt, is cured in 60. daies.

div.p: Fractura vlnae vel radij, ſi per ſe contingat, amborumVlnae vel radij. comminutione pericu loſior eſt.

p.hi: If one of the bones of the arme bee broken onely, it is more daungerous than the breaking of them both together.

div.p: Fracto membro applicanda ſunt doloris ſedatiua & apoſtemationisMedicamina fracto membro applicata. remouentia.

p.hi: The medicines which are applyed to fractures ought to aſſwage payne, and remoue impoſtumation.

div.p: Frigus, conuulſiones, tetanos, denigrationes, rigores febrilesFrigus. efficit.

p.hi: Cold cauſeth Cramps, ſtifneſſe of the ſinewes, blackneſſe and feuerous ſhiuerings.

div.p: Frigus inimicum eſt oſsibus, neruis, cerebro & dorſali medullae.

p.hi: Cold hurteth the bones, the ſinewes, the brayne, and the marrowe of the backe.

div.p: Frigida ſiſtunt ſanguinem poſita iuxta partes ſanguinolentas.

p.hi: Cold things do ſtay bloud, being layd nigh the bloudie parts.

div.head: G
div.p: GAngraena difficulter curatur, & ſi tranſit in ſphacelum, non niſi per ſectionem ſanatur.
Gangraena is hard to bee cured, and if it turne to Sphacelus, it cannot be cured but by inciſion.
Si carnem & neruum vſque ad os laedat, non curatur.
If Gangraena hurt the ſinewes and fleſh euen to the bone, it is vncurable.

div.head: H
div.p: HAemorrhagia prouenit aut per abundantiam, aut eroſionemVnde prouenit. vaſorum.

p.hi: Fluxe of bloud commeth either by abundance, or by corroding of the veſſels.

div.p: Haemorrhagia quae prouenit propter debilitatem cerebriPropter debilitatem cerebri. vix aut nunquam curatur.

p.hi: Fluxe of bloud which commeth by weakneſſe of the brayne, is hard or neuer cured.

div.p: Haemorrhagia è naribus quae extendit ſe vltra libras quatuorHaemorrhagioe è naribus quantitas. eſt mala, & ſi vltra octo, eſt peſsima, & ſi extendit ſe vſque ad xx. vel xxiiij. vltra viuere non poteſt.

p.hi: Bleeding at the noſe, if it exceede foure pound is euill, and if it come to eight it is moſt bad, and if it extend to twentìe or foure and twentie pound, he cannot liue any longer.

div.p: Haemorrhagia quae ducit ad colorem pallidum aut viridem,Ducens ad colorem pallidū aut viridem aut liuidum aut fuſcum. aut liuidum, aut fuſcum, peſsima eſt & mortalis.

p.hi: Bleeding which chaungeth the colour to bee pale, greene, ſwartiſh, or ſallowe, is very euill and deadly.

div.p: Haemorrhagia ducens ad ſyncopem, & ſi ſit cum frigiditateDucens ad ſyncopem. extremitatum eſt mortalis.

p.hi: Fluxe of bloud which cauſeth ſownding, is deadly: or if it bee with coldneſſe of the outward parts, it is alſo deadly.

div.p: Haemorrhagia quae venit ſubitò & cum impetu, eſt mala,Haemorrhagia ſubito accidens. ſi verò contingit cum alleuatione patientis, eſt bona.

p.hi: Bleeding at noſe that commeth ſodeinly and vyolently, is euill: but if the patient be lightned by it, it is good.

div.p: Haemorrhagia narium menſtruis deficientibus, bonum.Menſtruis deficientibus prodeſt.

p.hi: Bleeding at the noſe is profitable to them which want menſtrua.

div.p: Sanguis è naribus profluens, & aluus turbida, tollit ſurditatem.Tollit ſurditatem.

p.hi: Bleeding at the noſe and looſenes of the bellie, taketh away deaffnes.

div.p: Haemorrhagia in Haemorrhoidibus bonum.Haemor • hoydibus valet.

p.hi: Bleeding at the noſe to them that haue the Hemorhoydes, is very good.

div.p: Conuulſio ab hemorrhagia lethale.Conuulſio ab haemorrhagia.

p.hi: The Crampe comming after fluxe of bloud is deadly.

div.p: Fluxus haemorrhoidalis ſi ſit temperatus, facit multa iuuamenta, & praeſeruat à multis a gritudinibus melancholicisAegritudines à quibus • lu • us haemorrhoidalis praeſeruat, temperatus tamen. aduſtis, & corruptis, ſicut eſt mania, melancholia, pleureſis, lepra, morphea, hydropiſis, ptiſis, malum mortuum, quartana, paſsio ſplenis, &c.

If the fluxe of the Hemorhoydes be temperat, it bringeth many commodities, and preſerueth the bodie from aduſtion of humors: and many melancholike and corrupt diſeaſes, as Madneſſe, Melancholte, Pluriſie, Leproſie, Morphewe, Dropſie, • tiſicke, Malum morbum, a quartaine Agewe, diſeaſes of the Spleene, and ſuch like.
Si • luant vltra temperamentum, omnes praedictas aegritudinesFluxus haemor • hoydalis intemperatus. generant.

p.hi: If the Hemrhoydes doe ſlowe beyond the meaſure of the conſtitution, it bringeth all the aforeſayd diſeaſes.

div.p: Fluxus Hemorrhoidum temperatus cognoſcitur cumFluxus haemorrhoydum temperati cognitio. ſentiunt ſe alleuatos & melius comedentes.

p.hi: The temperate fluxe of the Hemrhoydes is knowne when the patient feeleth him ſomewhat light and eaſed withall, and hath a good appetite to his meate.

div.p: Cum autem ſentiunt ſe grauiores, cum malitia appetitus,Fluxus haemorrhoydum ſuperflu • cognitio. & cum foedo colore, tunc iam ſuperfluit fluxus, quare ſtatim conſtringendus eſt.

p.hi: But when the patient feeleth himſelfe ſad and heauie, with naughtie appetite, and filthie colour, it is a ſigne that the
fluxe hath paſſed the iuſt temperature: and therfore it ought to be ſtayed preſently.

div.p: Hemorrhoides curant melancholiam & nephrtiicamMelancholiam & neph • eticam paſsionem curant. Fluxus antiquus. paſsionem.

p.hi: The Hemorrhoydes do cure melancholie & payne of the back.

div.p: Si fluxus haemorroidum ſit antiquus non omnes ſubitò reſtringantur, ſed vna remaneat aperta.

p.hi: If fluxe of the Hemorrhoyd veynes hath continued long, they ought not all to be ſuddainely ſtayed, but one muſt be left open.

div.p: Curati citius pereunt, non curati, i. paliati longo temporeCura. viuunt.

p.hi: They that be cured of the Hemorrhoydes of long cōtinuance do dye ſoone, but if they be not cured but kept open, they liue long.

div.p: Hernia carnoſa raro aut nunquam ſine inciſione curatur.
Hernia carnoſa is hard or neuer cured without inciſion.
Hernia ventoſa cruciatus ingentes febrimque excitat, & niſi accuratè reſpicitur periculoſa valde eſt.
Hernia ventoſa bringeth great torments, and a Feuer, and except the carefully looked vnto, it is very dangerous.
Hernia aquoſa ſi ſemel teſtem humore ſuo vileſcit, difficilè aut nunquam abſque inciſione medetur.
Hernia aquoſa, if once the humor hath defiled the teſticle, it is hardly or neuer cured without inciſion.
Hernia varicoſa propter varices inflatas & circa teſticulam incraſſatas difficillimè abſque inciſione ſanatur.
Hernia varicoſa by reaſon of the ſwelled veynes that are puffed vp, and thickned about the teſticle, is hard to be cured without inciſion.
Hernia zirbialis inueterata rarò aut nunquam ſine inciſione curatur.

Hernia zirbialis of long continuance, is hardly or neuer cured
without inciſion.
Hernia inteſtinalis in ſenibus difficilè curatur.
Hernia inteſtinalis in old perſons is hard to be cured.
Hernia humoralis inueterata teſtem putreſcit, ideoque non niſi per inciſionem curatur.
Hernia humoralis of continuance doth putrifie the teſticle, therefore it can not be cured without inciſion.
Hernia inguinalis ſaepenumero in apoſtemationem degenerat, in fine quoque ſi non celeriter ſuccuratur, in fiſtulam vel vlcus cancroſum vadit.
Hernia inguinalis turneth oftentimes into impoſtumation, and in the end, if it be not ſpeedely cured, it either becommeth to be a fiſtula, or a canckrous vlcer.
Hernia ſanioſa difficillimè niſi in principio auxiliatur, quoniam materia eius venenoſa, non ſolum vnum teſticulum in quo oritur, verum etiam alterū corrumpit.
Hernia ſanioſa is hardly cured, except it be taken in time, for the poyſoned matter therein conteined, doth not onely corrupt the teſticle which it began in, but alſo put •• fieth the other.
Hernia zirbialis, inteſtinalis & ventoſa, ſemper ſi tempeſtiuè accipiantur, victus ratione & ligatura conuenienti aut leuantur aut penitus ſanantur.
Hernia zirbialis, inteſtinalis & ventoſa, are alwayes eaſed or cured by truſſes, in time, and by good dyet.
Hernia ventoſa medicamentis calefacientibus & ſlatum diſcutientibus curatur.
Hernia ventoſa is cured by medicines warming and diſſoluing winde.
Hernia aquoſa per actuale cauterium inter burſam & teſticulum optimè curatur.
Hernia aquoſa is beſt cured by an actuall cautery betwéene the codde and the teſticle.
Omnis hernia initio, praeſertim in pueris facillime curatur.

p.hi: Euery rupture in the beginning, eſpecially in children, is eaſie to be cured.

div.p: Omnis hernia cum dolore ac inguinum tumore difficilè curatur.

p.hi: Euery rupture with payne and ſwelling of the flancks, is hard to be cured.

div.p: Hernia cum Hydrope let hale eſt.

p.hi: A rupture with a dropſey is deadly.

div.p: Hernia nulla per inciſionem, ſine vnius teſticuli amiſsione curatur.

p.hi: There is no rupture cured by inciſion, but that one of the teſticles is taken away.

div.p: Hernia vltra ſeptem dies, antiquata appellatur, quoniam tunc labia vulneris interius indurata ſunt.

p.hi: A rupture after ſeauen dayes is called old, becauſe then the lips of the breach in wardly are hardned.

div.p: Relaxatio ſine inciſione in principio facilè curatur.

p.hi: A relaxation is eaſily cured in the beginning without inciſion.

div.p: Relaxatio facilius quam hernia completa curatur.

p.hi: A relaxation is eaſier cured then a rupture complete.

div.p: Differentia inter relaxationem & rupturam hoc modo cognoſcitur, ſi aliquis ſtet ſupra pedes ſuos & impellat anhelitum verſus inferiora, ſi de facili tunc deſcendant inteſtina inferius, ruptus eſt, ſi non, relaxatus eſt.

p.hi: The difference betweene a relaxation and a rupture, is thus knowne, let him that doubteth, by reaſon of ſome ſtrayne, whether he be broken or no, ſtand vpon his feete, and force his breath towards the inferior parts, if then the entrailes do eaſily deſcend downewards, he is broken, if not, he is but relaxed.

div.p: Lues venerea ſe omnibus coniungit aegritudinibus, aegritudineſqueLues venerea. omnes in genere ſecum aſſociat.
Lucs vencrea ioyneth with all diſeaſes, and all diſeaſes do ioyne with it.
Lucs venerea con • agioſa eſt, ſi cum mulieribus immundis coitu accidit.

p.hi: This diſeaſe is contagious, if it chanceth through carnall copulation with vncleane women.

div.p: Cauſa antecedens eſt quando humores per malignitatem,Cauſa anteccdens. & morbi contagioſi venenoſam qualitatem corripiuntur.

p.hi: The antecedent cauſe is, when the humors are defiled by the malignitie and venemous qualitie of the diſeaſe being contagious.

div.p: Cauſa primitiua eſt coitus cum mulieribus immundis atqueCauſa primitiua. foedis, puſtulas venenoſas in vtero habentibus.

p.hi: The primitiue cauſe of this diſeaſe, is carnall company with vncleane and filthy women, hauing venemous puſtles in their ſecret partes.

div.p: Poſtquam lues venerea in ſecretis partibus oritur, adeò venenoſa eſt, vt per totum corpus tranſit, a capite ad pedes.

p.hi: After lues venerea hath begun in the ſecret parts, it is ſo venemous, that it ſpreadeth through the whole body, from the head to the foote.

div.p:
Sanguis in lue venerea vniuerſaliter corrumpitur, ideo
que
Producit, puſtulas, ſcabies venenoſas ſquamaſque c • uſtoſas. puſtulas, ſcabies venenoſas, ſquamaſque cruſtoſas producit.

p.hi: In lues venerea the bloud is corrupted through the whole body, and ſo produceth puſtles, venemous ſcabbes, and cruſty ſcales.

div.p: In luis venereae curatione, neque anodina, neque paliatiuaQuae medicine fugienda ſunt in luis vene • cae curatione. Lentigines. medicamenta adhibeantur.

p.hi: In the cure of lues venerea, neyther aſſwaging, nor palliatiue medicines are to be vſed.

div.p:
Lentigines ſunt infectiones cutis faciei, vt plurimum, &
aliquando cutis totius corporis.

p.hi: Freckles are infections (for the moſt part) of the ſkinne of the face, and ſometimes of the ſkinne of the whole bodie.

div.p:
In lentiginibus ſi corpus fuerit vniuerſaliter multum repletumI en • i • i ••• in co • po • en ••
tum rep ••• o. ſiat phlebotomia de baſilica.

p.hi: In a ſreckled bodie, if the bodie be much replete vniuerſally, it is good to open the baſilica veyne.

div.p: Si autem non fuerit tanta repletio, & infectio fuerit in totoSi ſue • t in to to corpore, ſi in facie. corpore fiat de Mediana, & ſi in facie fiat de Cephalica.
But if there be no ſuch repletion, and the infection be through the whole bodie, then open Mediana: but if it be only in the face open Cephalica.

Scarificationes in tibijs, aut inter ſpatulas, aut ſub mentoBona vtenda in lentige ••
bus. multum valent in lentiginibus.

p.hi: For freckles, ſcarifications of the legs, or betwixt the ſhoulderblades, or vnder the chinne, doe greatly profite.

div.p: Lepra eſt morbus conſimilis corrumpens figuram & formam,Lepra. & compoſitionem membrorum & finaliter ſoluens continuum, proueniens de materia melancholica ſparſa per totum corpus.

p.hi: The Leproſie is a diſeaſe of like maners, corrupting the figure, forme and compoſition of the members: and finally making breach of continuitie, it commeth of melancholike matter diſperſed through the whole bodie.

div.p: Lepra poſtquam venit ad manifeſtam corruptionem formaeLepra ad manifeſtam corruptionem accedens. & figurae non curabitur, ſed vitam prolongare poſſumus, & impedire cū medicaminibus, ne materia venenoſa & melancholica, ad cor & membra principalia vadat.

p.hi: After that the Lepro • e commeth to manifeſt corruption of the forme and figure, it is vncurable: but we may prolong life, and hinder by medicines that the venimous and melancholike matter come not to the heart and principall members.

div.p: Lepra incipit primò ab interioribus, & poſtea manifeſtabiturLeprae initiū. in facie & extremitatibus, & iterata reuertitur ad interiora; & tunc eſt mors, quia membra nobilia ruinam ſuſtinere non poſſunt.

p.hi: The Leproſie beginneth firſt from the inward parts, and after is diſcerned in the face and outwarde parts, and being renewed turneth to the inward parts againe; and then commeth death, becauſe the principall members cannot ſuſteyne ruine.

div.p: Lippitudo obeſis corporibus & aetate confectis ſine aliquoLippitudo. incomodo nunquam curatur.

p.hi: Blear • dnes in fat and olde perſons is neuer cured without a diſcommoditie.

div.head: M
De Medicamentis.
div.p:
MEdicamina calida corporibus ſiccis macilentiſ
que applicataMedicamina 〈…〉 . calorem humiditatémque naturalem extingunnt.

p.hi: Hote medicines applyed to drie and leane bodies, doe extiuguiſh naturall heate and moyſture.

div.p: Deſiccantibus non indigent quatuor haec, viz. vlcus contuſum,Deſiccantibus non indigent 4. hac. diſtractum, doloroſum, & apoſtemoſum.

p.hi: Theſe foure noede no deſiccatiues: that is to ſay, an vlcer with contuſion, an vlcer with diſtracted lippes, an vlcer with payne or impoſtumation.

div.p: Nimis infrigidantia, vlcera nigri coloris, & cerulei reddunt.Infrigidantia nimia.

p.hi: Exceſſiue cooling medicines doe cauſe vleets to be blacke and blew of colour.

div.p: Incarnatiua abſtergere minimè debent.Incarnantia.

p.hi: Incarnatiues ought not to wipe.

div.p: Incarnantia antequam mundificandi vim habent, applicata, ſuperſ • uam carnoſitatem generant.

p.hi: Intarnatiues vſed before mundi •• catiues, doe cauſe proude fleſh.

div.p: Quae ad inijciendum conueniunt neceſſe habent vt cumAd 〈…〉 n • unt. melle roſarum, allumine, lixiuioque vel aqua marina, quoniam talia obſcoenitatem abſumunt & humorem defendunt, conficiantur.

p.hi: Medicines conuenient for iniections muſt bee made with Mel roſarum, Alume, Lee, or ſalt-water, becauſe they take away filthie matter, and defend the humour.

div.p:
Medicamina locis neruoſis, venoſis, & arterioſis, vel circaLocis, ne •• oſi • ven • ſis & ar
• er • ſis vel circa teſ •• culos medicamina applicata. teſticulos applicanda, ob earum partium ſenſibilitatem facillima ſint oportet, ſed ſuper ligamenta fortiora poſsint applicari.

p.hi: Thoſe medicines which are applyed to ſinewie, veynie, and arterious places, or about the teſticles, ought to bee gentle by reaſon of the ſenſibilitie of thoſe parts: but about the ligaments ſtronger may be vſed.

div.p: In carne vlcerata ſi peracutus ſit ſenſus, cauendum à cauſticisCarne ••• rat • cum ſenſu per • cu •• . & ab omnibus peracutis medicamentis.

p.hi: In vlcerated fleſh, if there bee moſt ſharpe ſence, take heede of Cauſticke and all ſharpe medicines.

div.p: Corpora imbecilla atque loca ſenſibilia leues medicinasCorpora imbecilla atque loca ſenſibilia. applicari quaerunt.

p.hi: Weake bodies and tender places doe require ſoft and gentle medicines.

div.p: Medicamina vnctuoſa minime conueniunt, niſi aliorumMedicamina vn • tno • a. acuitatum auferendi cauſa.

p.hi: Unctuous medicines are not conuenient, except for the taking away of others ſharpnes.

div.p: Medicamen incarnans deſiccare quoque oportet ac aliquantumMedicam •• incarna • s. excedere naturale membri temperamentum.

p.hi: An incarnatiue medicine ought alſo to drie, and ſomewhat to exceede the naturall temperature of the member.

div.p: Concaui vlceris cura per exiccationem & mundificationemConcaui vlceris cura. aggreditur.

p.hi: A hollowe vlcer is cured by exiccatiues and mundificatiues.

div.p: Medicamina exiccantia teneris humidiſque corporibusMedicamina exiccantia. conſentiunt.

p.hi: Exiccatiue medicines are expedient for tender and moyſt bodies.

div.p: Membra humida magna exiccatione non egent.Membra humida.

p.hi: Moyſt members neede not great drying.

div.p: Deſiccantia & cicatrizantia, non autem mollificantia, vlceribusMedicinae quoe conueniunt vlceribus mulie • ū in partibus pudibundis. mulierum, in partibus pudibundis, conueniunt.

p.hi: Deſiccatiue and cicatrizing medicines are conuenient for vlcers about the priuities of women: and not mollificatiues.

div.p: Exiccantia admittit ſanies tenuis & acuta▪ è contra craſſaSanies tenuis & acuta, craſſa & denſa. & denſa abſtergentia.

p.hi: Thinne and ſharpe matter requireth exiccatiues: and contrarily thicke and groſſe, abſterſiues.

div.p: Vlceribus conferentia tum exiccare tum abſtergere debent.Vlceribus conferentia.

p.hi: Thoſe medicines which doe both drie and wipe are moſt expedient for vlcers.

div.p: Digerentia vulneribus detritis in primis, poſteaque quaeVulneribus detritis quae vtenda ſunt. mundificandi vim habent adhibeantur.

p.hi: Digeſtiues muſt firſt of all be vſed to bruſed woundes, and afterward mundificatiues.

div.p: Incarnantia vulneribus concauis ante ea quae conſolidentVulneribus concauis. expediunt.

p.hi: Incarnatiues are expedient to be vſed in hollow woundes before conſolidatiues.

div.p: Quaecunque per triduum nihil valent, adhibita, poſtquamNota generalis. reijcienda.

p.hi: Thoſe medecines which in thrée dayes compaſſe preuaile nothing, are afterward to be reiected.

div.p: Melancholia aut ſpargitur ad totum corpus, aut ad partem:Melancholia quomodo corpus excitat. Feb▪ melanchol. Lepra. Morph •• . ſi ad totum, aut putrefit aut non: ſi putrefiat, tum generatur febris melancholica: ſi non putrefiat, tunc aut mittitur ad carnem aut cutem; ſi ad carnem, generat Lepram, ſi ad cutem, morpheam.

p.hi: Melancholy is either diſperſed thorough the whole bodie, or to part thereof: if it be ſent to the whole body, it doth either putrifie, or not: if it putrifie, then it cauſeth a melancholike Feuer: if it do not putrifie, then it is ſent eyther to the fleſh, or to the ſkinne; if it be ſent to the fleſh, it engendreth the Leproſie; if it be ſent to the ſkinne, it cauſeth the morphew.

div.p: Melancholia eſt mater caecitatis, apoplexiae, ſpaſmi &Caecitatem apoplexiam ſpaſmum & furorem excitat. furoris.

p.hi: Melancholy is the mother of blindneſſe, apoplexie▪ cramps, and madneſſe.

div.p: Melancholiae ſigna ſunt metus & triſtitia.Melancholiae ſigna.

p.hi: The ſignes of melancholy are feare and ſadneſſe.

div.p: Membri alicuius amputatione tria praecipue ſunt conſideranda.Membri amputatione conſiderationes.

p.hi: In the cutting off of any member, thrée things are chiefly to be conſidered.

div.p:
Primò, vt fiat ſine dolore inciſio.
•

p.hi: Firſt, that the inciſion be made without payne.

div.p:
Secundò, vt ſanguinis vitetur fluxus.
•

p.hi: Secondly, that fluxe of bloud may be eſchued.

div.p:
Tertio, vt cauterizetur ſiue actualiter, ſiue potentialiter,
•
tam exiguo cum dolore vt arte inueniri queat.

p.hi: Thirdly, that the cautery eyther actuall or potentiall be done with as little payne as may be deuiſed by arte.

div.p: Morphea eſt cutis defoedatio maculoſa.Morphea.

p.hi: The Morphewe is a ſpotty filthineſſe of the ſkinne.

div.p:
Si morphea fuerit nouella, curabilis eſt, ſi antiqua, incurabilisVtrum morphea ſit cura
eſt: vel cum magna difficultate.bilis aut incurabilis.

p.hi: If the Morphew be of ſmall continuance, it is curable, but if it be of long continuance, it is hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: Si morphea occupauerit modicum ſpatium, curabilis eſt, ſi magnum, difficilis.

p.hi: If the Morphew be contained in ſmall ſpace, it is curable, but if it ſpreade very farre, it is hard to be cured.

div.p: Si locus morpheatus pungatur cum acu in ſuperficie cutis, ita vt non profundetur vltra cutem & ſanguis exierit, curabilis eſt, ſi autem aquoſitas, incurabilis eſt, aut cum magna difficultate.

p.hi: If the place that is affected with the Morphewe be pricked with a néedle in the vpper part of the ſkinne (ſo that it goe not paſt the ſkinne) and that the bloud doth iſſue out, it is curable, but if moiſture come foorth, it is hard or neuer cured.

div.p: In morphea a principio, ſanguine dominante aut corporePhlebotomia in morphea. plethorico exiſtente, materiaque morpheae in venis adhuc remanente bene poteſt fieri phlebotomia, ſed poſtquam notabiliter apparet extra, & aegritudo ſit confirmata, nullo modo adhibeatur, quia materia traheretur ab externis ad interiora.

p.hi: In the Morphewe, bloudletting may well be vſed, at the beginning when blond doth abound, or in a bodie full of euill humors, and the matter of the Morphewe remayning yet in the veynes, but after it doth manifeſtly appeare outwardly, and that the diſeaſe be confirmed, bloudletting may in no wiſe be vſed, becauſe the matter thereby would be drawne from the outward parts inwardly.

div.p: Membrorum durities a tribus caſibus euenit, nempe a calore nimio, ab humorum coagulatione & a repletione.

p.hi: There be thrée cauſes of hardneſſe in any member, as great heate, the impaction of humors coagulated, and fulneſſe.

div.p: Cognita, & vſu ac ratione probata, remedia, ignotis ac nunc primum inuentis ſunt praeponenda.

p.hi: Thoſe medecines which are knowne and approued both by reaſon and experience, are to be preferred before thoſe which are vnknowne, and but newly inuented.

div.p: Non verbis ſed remedijs conuenienter vſurpatis reſtituitur ſanitas.

p.hi: Health is not reſtored by words, but by medecines conue mently vſed.

div.p: Scientia ſine experientia haud magnam medico apud aegrum fiduciam conciliat.

p.hi: Knowledge without practiſe, winneth to the Phyſition ſmall credit of his Patient.

div.p: Praxis eſt operatio, theoriae regulis & legibus cōfentiens.

p.hi: Practiſe is an operation agréeable to the rules and lawes of Theoricke.

div.p: Artifex qui magnum aliquid & laude dignum praeſtare vult, in notitiam proprij ſubiecti diligenter debot incumbere.

p.hi: That workeman which would ſhew ſome great things that is praiſe-worthie, let him diligently apply himſelfe to the knowledge of his proper ſubiect.

div.p: Boni medici officium eſt morbum ſanare, aut certe in meliorem ſtatum, & eum, quem natura fert, deducere.

p.hi: It is the office of a good artiſt to heale the diſeaſe, or to bring it into a better ſtate, and that which agréeth to nature.

div.p: Qui artis operibus, doctiſque de arte lectionibus frequens non interfuit: hocque ſolo, quod multa legerit, ſe pro nobili chirurgo venditat, longe fallitur, & impudens eſt.

p.hi: He that hath not béen conuerſant in the works of the Arte, nor at the Lectures of the learned, but eſtéemeth himſelfe for an excellent Surgeon, by this onely, that he hath read many things, is farre deceiued, and very impudent.

div.p: Nihil vnquam laude dignum praeſtabit qui ſibi auro non vſu chirurgicum magiſterium parauerit.

p.hi: He ſhall neuer perfourme any thing worthy prayſe, which obtaineth the degrée of a Surgeon by money, and not by vſe.

div.p: Medicos & chirurgos ſubinde mutare, aegris raedium non leuamen eſt.

p.hi: To change often the Phyſitions and Chirurgions, is a burdening, and not a lightning to the Patient.

div.p: Etſi in longum tempus ſe morbus protrahat, non eſt tamen quod ſe ab aegro medīcus diſtrahat.

p.hi: Although the diſeaſe continue a long time, yet it is not for the Phyſition to withdrawe himſelfe from the Patient.

div.p: Magna magnorum vaſorum vulnera lethalia cenſentur.

p.hi: Great wounds in the great veſſels, are eſtéemed deadly.

div.p: Vt morbi ſic remedij ſpecies eſſe debet.

p.hi: As the kinds of the diſeaſe are, ſo ought the kinds of the remedies to be.

div.p: Oſsise palato abſceſſus putroris inſert periculum.

p.hi: The ſwelling of the bone out of the palate, bringeth danger of putrefaction.

div.p: Haemorthagiam calor incitat, frigus refraenat.

p.hi: Heate moueth bléeding at the noſe, but cold reſtrayneth the ſame.

div.p: Quibus vlcera in cruribus ſunt, hos neque ambulare, neque ſtare, neque ſedere, ſed in lecto quieſcere oportet.

p.hi: They that haue vlcers in their legges, muſt neyther walke, ſtand, nor ſit, but lye in their bed.

div.p: Mordacia & acria omnia medicamina mundis vlceribus ſunt infenſa.

p.hi: All manner ſharpe and biting medecines are hurtfull to cleane vlcers.

div.p: Auſtro flante vulneratorum membrorum prompta eſt ſyderatio.

p.hi: When the Southerne winde bloweth, the partes are more diſpoſed to putrefaction.

div.p: Vlcera rotunda niſi in aliam figuram deducta fuerint non facilè coaleſcunt.

p.hi: Round vlcers, except they be reduced into another figure, are hardly cured.

div.p: Vlcus eryſipelatoſum purgationem per inferiora poſtulat.

p.hi: An vlcer with Eryſipelas requireth purging by the inferiour parts.

div.p: Nemini niſi abdominoſo triſtitia prodeſt.

p.hi: Sadnes is profitable to none, ſaue only to them that are corpulent and foggie.

div.p: Ignauia calorem naturalem debilitat & extinguit.

p.hi: Slouthfulneſſe weakneth and extinguiſheth naturall heate.

div.p: Morbi frigidi ſenibus ſunt infenſi ac ſolutu contumaces: inuenibus vero non ita infeſti & rebelles.

p.hi: Cold diſeaſes are hurtfull to olde men, and very hard to be reſolued: but to young men not ſo troubleſome and rebellious.

div.head: O
div.p: OEdema vt plurimum terminatur per reſolutionemEius terminatio. ſeu exhalationem, raro per ſuppurationem, ſaepiſsimè per conuerſionem ſeu permutationem in nodos & alia apoſtemata.
Oedema for the moſt part is cured by reſoluing or euaporation, ſeldome by ſuppuration, and very often by turning or chaunging into knots or other impoſtumes.

Quandiu lippa eſt aquoſa & ſubtilis, aegritudo eſt in principio,Principium. & cum incipit ingroſſari & dealbari tunc eſt in augmento, & cum lippa eſt multa, claudens palpebras,Augmentum. Status. tunc eſt ſtatus: & cum incipit minui, tunc eſt declinatio: & lippa quae habet fruſta parua eſt mala, ſicut dicit Auicenna.

When the blearednes is watriſh and thinne, than the diſe aſe is in the beginning: and when it waxeth thicke and white, than it is in the augmentation: and when the blearednes is great, cloſing the eylids, than it is in the ſtate; and when that beginneth to diminiſh, than it is in the declining: and blearednes which hath little peeces is euill, as Auicen ſayth.
Opthalmia quae eſt in hieme cum particularibus concurrentibusOpthalmia in hieme. in frigiditate, tardius venit & tardius recedit, & eſt magis periculoſa propter clauſionem pororum.
That Opthalmia which chaunceth in winter with particulars concurring in coldneſſe, hapneth ſlowly and goeth away ſlowly, and is more daungerous by reaſon of the ſhutting of the pores.
Illa autem quae eſt in aeſtate, citius venit & citius recedit.Opthalmia in aeſtate.

p.hi: That Opthalima which is in Sommer time, commeth ſooner, and goeth away ſooner.

div.p: Opthalmia ſi malè curetur malas reliquias dimittit ſicutReliquie opthalmiae. eſt macula, pannus, tela, & ita de alijs.
If Opthalmia bee not well cured, it leaueth behinde it euill reliques, ſuch as is the bloudie ſpot, pannicle, webbe, and ſuch like.
Opthalmia quae antiquatur, in qua non proficiunt medicamina, eſt peſsima inter omnes, quoniam ſignificatur humor corruptus inuiſcatus, corrumpens nutrimentum.
Opthalmia, that is inueterated wherein medicines are not auaileable is the worſt of all, becauſe it ſignifieth a corrupt ſlimie humour corrupting the nouriſhment.
Si panaritio non ſubitò ſuccurritur, corrumpit primam iuncturam digiti, quae cum oſſe deperditur & manat ab eo ſanies ſubtilis foetida, quando ad putredinem deuenit.

p.hi: If a felon be not ſpeedily helped, it putrifleth the firſt ioynt of
the finger, which together with the bone is vtterly loſt, and when it commeth to putrifaction there floweth from it thin ſtinking matter.

div.p:
Infrigidantia à principio ſunt applicanda ad confirmationemMedican i • a qua panant •• ſunt applicanda à 〈…〉
prohibendam, ſed poſt principium eorum vſus inculcat materiam, & auget dolorem.

p.hi: Cold things muſt bee applped in the beginning to hinder the confirming of the griefe, but the vſe of them after the beginning, impacteth the matter and encreaſeth the payne.

div.p: Si videris hoc apoſtema ad exituram diſponi, applica maturantia, & cura eo modo, quo aliae exiturae curantur.

p.hi: If you perceiue this impoſtume to growe to a tumor, applie maturatiues, and cure it in that order as other tumors require.

div.p: Verum ſi dolor intenſiſsimus perſeueret, & nullum appareat ſignum exiturae futurae, finde digitum lateraliter ab vngue vſque ad os, & ſtatim ſedabit dolor.

p.hi: But if the intollerable payne doe remayne, and no ſigne of any tumor appeare, then make inciſion all along the firſt ioynt of the finger hard by the ſide of the naile to the very bone, and preſently the payne will ceaſe.

div.p: Omnes puſtulae ſi negligantur & non mundificentur inIn ſcabiem conuertuntur. ſcabiem conuertuntur.

p.hi: All puſtules if they be neglected, and not mundified, they turne into ſcabbes.

div.p: Puſtulae ſi fuerint de cauſa calida ad impetiginem & ſerpiginemDecauſa calida ad imperiginem & ſerpiginem vergunt. & alia mala accidentia vergunt.
Puſtules that come of a hote cauſe doe turne to Impetigo, and Serpigo, and other euill accidents.
Si autem fuerint de phlegmate poſt ſcabiem in fiſtulam conuertuntur.

p.hi: Puſtules that come of flegme after the Scabbe doe turne to aDe phlegmate. Fiſtula.

div.p: Si fuerint de melancholia difficilè curantur.De melancholia.

p.hi: Puſtules that come of melancholie are hard to be cured.

div.p: Puſtulae liuidae in vlla parte corporis emergentes, citoquePuſtulae liuidae. euaneſcentes malum portendunt.

p.hi: Puſtules that bee of ſwartiſh colour appearing in any part of the bodie, and ſodainly vaniſhing away, are a ſigne of eutll.

div.p: Putredo oritur cum vapores humidi in membro includuntur; & ibi adeo impediti ſunt, vt euaporari nequeunt.

p.hi: Putrefaction commeth when moyſt vapors are included within the member, ſo as they cannot cuaporate.

div.p: In putredinem humiditas & calor cito tranſeunt, ſi non bono regimine gubernentur.

p.hi: Moyſture and heate being not well gouerned, will ſpeedily turne to putrefaction.

div.p: Putredo à narcoticis nonnunquam accidit.

p.hi: Putrefaction is often cauſed by the application of ſlupefactiue medicines.

div.head: S
De Sanguine.
div.p: SAnguis tenuis, totum per corpus non diſperſus, externaSanguis tenuis ſola inflammat, eryſipelas nothum generans.
Thinne bloud not diſperſed through the whoſe bodie, • nſlameth the outward parts, cauſing a baſtard Eryſipelas.
Sanguis ſubſtantia groſſus & calidus carbunculos parit.Sanguis groſſus & calidus.

p.hi: Bloud that is groſſe in ſubſtaunce and hate, cauſeth Carbuncles.

div.p: Sanguinis naturalis copia phlegmonem parit.Sanguis naturalis.

p.hi: Abundance of naturall bloud cauſeth Biles.

div.head: Iudicium de ſanguine emiſſo, ex ſubſtantia.
div.p:
SErum multum tanquam aqua citrina concreto ſanguiniSerum multum. innatans, vel potum liberaliorem vel iecur infirmum,
vel imbecilles renes vel eoſdem obſtructos oſtendit.

p.hi: Much whey like vnto yellow water, ſwimming aloft of congealed bloud, ſheweth either much drinking, or a weake Lyuer: or weake or ſtopped kidneyes.

div.p:
Spuma innatans niſi fluoris impetu nata eſt, incendium,Spum •
atque feruorem eius humoris monſtrat, cuius colorem prae ſe fert: rubra quidem, ſanguinis; flaua, bilis▪ alba, pituitae; liuida, melancholiae.

p.hi: Froth ſwimming aloft, except it be by the force of the fluxe, ſheweth burning and heate of that humor, whoſe colour it beareth, as if it be red, it cōmeth of bloud, yellow, of choller, white, of flegme, ſwartiſh, of melancholy.

div.p:
Sanguinis dureſcentis color per ſumma rubicundus, boniColor rub •
▪cundus. vtiliſque ſanguinis eſt index.

p.hi: The colour of congealed bloud being red aboue, is a ſigne of good and profitable bloud.

div.p: Sanguini innatat nonnunquam pingue quiddam & adipoſumPingued • . inſtar telae aranei cohaerens: hoc, ſi admodum pingue & obeſum ſit corpus, ex ipſo ſanguine cauſam habet, qui eſt in adipem pronus. Sin corpus ſtrigoſius ſit minuſque obeſum, idipſum colliquari & marceſcere portendit.

p.hi: There ſwimmeth ſometimes in the bloud a certaine fatneſſe, cleauing together like a Spiders webbe: if the body be very fat, it was cauſed of ſuch bloud, which is enclined to fatneſſe: but if the bodie be verie leane, the ſame is a ſigne of the withering and decay thereof.

div.p: Si diffiſo ſanguine, grana quaedam arenularum aemula offendantur:Gra •• arenularum. aiunt vel elephantiaſin vel ad hanc propenſionem notari: quanquam obſeruantibus nihil tale deprehenſum eſt.

p.hi: If in the bloud being cut, certayne graynes like ſand be found, ſome ſay it ſignifieth the Leproſy, or an inclination thereunto, although they that haue obſerued, haue not
found it any ſuch thing.

div.p:
Si ſanguinem grauè olere (quod rarum eſt) contigerit,Gra ••
• lens. putredinis corruptioniſque immenſae eſt inditium.

p.hi: If it chance that the bloud ſtincketh, which hapneth ſeldome, it is a ſigne of very great putrefaction and corruption.

div.p: Scabies in decrepitis eſt difficilis curationis aut impoſſibilis.Scabies in decrepitis.

p.hi: The Scab in old age is very hard or vnpoſſible to be cured.

div.p: Scabies foeda vlceratione foetida, multas partes corporisScabies foeda cum vlceratione faetida. occupans, & corrumpens, habet malam radicem, & approximatur ad malas aegritudines, & difficilis curationis valde.

p.hi: A filthy Scab, with ſtincking vlceration, in many parts of the bodie corrupting, hath an euill roote, and draweth néere the nature of euil diſeaſes, being alſo very hard of curation.

div.p: Scabies ſi fuerit parua, modicam partem corporis occupans,Scabies parua. ſine magna anguſtia, & non ſomnum auferens, facilè curabitur, & e contrario contrariè.

p.hi: A ſmall Scab, occupying but a little part of the body, without any great anguiſh, and not diminiſhing ſléepe, is eaſily cured, and contrarywiſe, contraryly.

div.head: De Strumis.
div.p: Strumae paruae facilius curantur, magnae difficilius.Strumae paruae & magnae.

p.hi: Small wennes are eaſy to be cured, but great ones are hard.

div.p: Strumae mites facile curam recipiunt, malignae aegrè.Strumae mites & malignae.

p.hi: Wennes without payne and anguiſh are eaſy to be cured, but thoſe which are froward, will hardly receiue curation.

div.p: Strumae ſuperficiariae facilè ſanantur profundoe difficulter.Strumae ſuperficiariae & profundae. Stru • ae recentes & inuete • a • ae.

p.hi: Thoſe wennes which ſye néere the ſkinne are eaſy to be cured, but thoſe which lye deepe within the fleſh, are hard to cure.

div.p:
Strumae recentes diſcuti & reſolui poſſunt, inueteratae
diſcuti & reſolui nequeunt.

p.hi: Wennes of ſmall continuance may be reſolued, but thoſe which are inueterated, can not be reſolued.

div.p: Dolor & calor oſtendunt ſtrumam vel in ſuppurationemDolor aut calor. ire vel in fiſtulam aut cancrum degenerari.

p.hi: Payne and heate in a wenne, declareth the ſame eyther to turne to ſuppuration, or elſe into a Fiſtulae or Cancker.

div.p: Qui breui atque anguſta ſunt fronte, & compreſſa habentQui ſtru ••• obnoxij ſu •• . tēpora, ac maxillas amplas, ſtrumis ſunt obnoxij.

p.hi: They that haue a ſhort and narrow forhead, and their temples compaſſed with large iawes, are incident to haue wennes.

div.p:
Strumae non facilè matureſcunt & plerun
que iterum iuxta cicatrices ipſas reſurgunt.

p.hi: Wennes are hardly ripened, and oftentimes they do riſe agayne beſide the cicatrices.

div.head: T.
div.p: TInea eſt ſcabies capitis cū ſquammis & pilorum euulſione,Tinea quid▪ & colore cinericeo, & odore foetido & aſpectu abhominabili.
Tinea, or the ſkall, is a ſcabbe of the head, with ſcales, and falling of the heare, in colour like vnto aſhes, ſtincking ſauour, and in ſight abhominable.

Tinea ſi ſit recens tamen cum difficultate curatur.Tinea 〈◊〉
▪

p.hi: A ſkall if it be new, yet is it hard to be cured.

div.p: Si ſit antiqua aut nunquam, aut cum labore magno, & inTinea antiqua▪ longiſsimo tempore; quoniam mala complexio venit ad tantam adaequationem, quod quaſi non accipit curationem, & ideo ſi curetur raro ibi pili naſcuntur & illa pars ſemper erit debilior.

p.hi: If the ſkall be olde, it is neuer cured, or with great laboure, and in long time, becauſe that euill complexion commeth to ſuch equalitie, that it cannot almoſt receiue curation, and therefore if it be cured, the haire will ſeldome
growe in that place agayne, and that part wil be alwayes weaker.
De Tumoribus.

div.p: TVmores ex flegmate nati ſunt vt plurimum indolentes.Tumores a flegmate.

p.hi: Tumors that proceed of flegme, are for the moſt part without griefe.

div.p: Tumores de atra bile orti ſemper doloroſi.Tumores de • tra bile.

p.hi: Tumors proceeding of melancholy, are alwayes greeuous.

div.p: Tumores de flaua bile & ſanguine nati nunquam dolore deſtituuntur.Tumore de flaua bile & ſanguine.

p.hi: Tumors comming of yellow choller and bloud, are neuer without great payne.

div.p: Tumor durus circa teſtes, cum carnis excretione, difficulterCirca teſtes tumor durus. curatur.

p.hi: A hard tumor about the teſticles, with excretion of the fleſh, is hard to be cured.

div.p: Tumor ceruicis promittit ſalutem in angina.Tumor ceruicis.

p.hi: A tumor in the throate, betokeneth health in Angina.

div.p: Tumores concocti ſunt molles, crudi vero duri.Tumore▪ molles & dun.

p.hi: Ripe tumors are ſoft, but vnripe are hard.

div.head: V.
De Venae ſectione.
div.p: TEmpus in quo venae ſectio vtenda venit a februarioTempus in quo venae ſectio ſit vtenda. incipit, & rurſus a ſeptembri, ad ſeptimum eiuſdem perdurans.

p.hi: The time when letting of bloud muſt be vſed, beginneth at February, and agayne at September, enduring to the ſeauenth day thereof.

div.p: Venam ſaepius incidere in anno non expedit.Saepe in anno venam incidere. Obſtructiones curat.

p.hi: It is not good to be let bloud oft in one yeare.

div.p:
In obſtructionibus curandis, ante omnia venam ſecare
oportet, etiamſi plenitudo non adſit.

p.hi: In the curing of obſtructions, letting of bloud before all other is to be vſed, although there be no fulnes.

div.p: Quouis tempore & hora mittere ſanguinem neceſsitasQuouis tempore & hora mittere ſanguinem. concedit & iubet.

p.hi: If neceſſitie doe require, Phlebotomie may bee vſed at any time.

div.p: Non dierum numerus ſed vnicum virium robur conſiderandumFit febribus continui • . in ſectione venae febrium continuarum.

p.hi: For Phlebotomie in continuall Feuers, not the number of daies, but onely the ſtrength of the partie is to bee conſidered.

div.p: A ſanguinis miſsione abſtinendum eſt vbi ſanguis bonusA ſanguinis miſsione vbi abſtinendum. exiguus eſt.

p.hi: Abſtayne from Phlebotomie where there is but a little good bloud.

div.p: Venae ſectio quaecunque & quouis modo facta aequabiliterTotum corpu • euacuat. totum corpus euacuat.

p.hi: Euery manner of letting of bloud doth equally euatuate the whole bodie.

div.p: Nullus paene morbus, in quo non mittatur ſanguis.In omni ſerè morbo valet.

p.hi: There is almoſt no diſeaſe wherein Phlebotomie may not be vſed.

div.p: Vehemens febris, vbi rubet corpus venaeque tument, ſanguinisFebris vehemens. detractionem requirit.

p.hi: A vehement Feuer where the bodie is red and the veynes doe ſwell, requireth letting of bloud.

div.p: Si timidè ſcalpellus dimittatur ſummam cutem lacerat nec venam incidit.

p.hi: If Phlebotomy be done fearfully, it doth but teare the ſkinne and miſſe the veyne.

div.p: Poſt longam aegritudinem, cauendum à phlebotomia.A phlebotomia cauendū.

p.hi: After long ſickneſſe beware of bloud-letting.

div.p: Tempore calidiſsimo, & frigidiſsimo, nullo modo fiatTempore calidiſſimo & frigidiſſimo. phlebotomia.

p.hi: In extremitie of wether, hote or colde, Phlebotomie ought in no wiſe to be vſed.

div.p: Ver & autumnus ſunt tempora aptiſsima phlebotomiae.Tempus in quo m • ttatur.

p.hi: The Spring and Autumne are moſt conuenient times for bloud-letting.

div.p: Aere exiſtente peſtilentiali, nubiloſo vel turbido aut ſlanteNon ſecetur vena. vento auſtrali non ſecetur vena.

p.hi: When the ayre is peſtilent, clowdie or troubled, or when the South winde bloweth, do not let bloud.

div.p: In aeſtate octaua hora et hieme meridies eligātur in phlebotomia.Hora phlebotomie • ligenda.

p.hi: In Sommer take eight of the Clocke, and in Winter, noone, for the houre of Phlebotomie.

div.p: Si luna ſit in ſigno habente aſpectum malum ad aliquodCautela. membrum non fiat phlebotomia de illo membro.

p.hi: If the Moone bee in any ſigne, hauing an euill aſpect to any member, do not let bloud on that member.

div.p: Ante Phlebotomiam bonum eſt exercitari, moueri, e • igilariAnte phlebotomiam. vt ſanguis ſit mobilior.

p.hi: Before bloudletting, it is good to be exerciſed, to moue, and to watch, whereby the bloud may be more moueable.

div.p: Membrum phlebotomandum eſt frigandum & calefaciendum,Membrum. cum aqua calida lauandum, vt vena ſit apertior & ſanguis fluxibilior.

p.hi: The member that you will let bloud muſt be chaffed and heated with hote water, that the veyne may bee more apparant and the bloud more fluent.

div.p:
Si phlebotomandus eſt valde debilis comedat prius panem
•• ſit debilis. & bibat vinum ſtipticum.

p.hi: If a weake bodie muſt bee let bloud, let him eate bread and drinke ſtiptick wine before.

div.p: In aeſtate & vere fiat phlebotomia in parte dextra, autumnoP ••• qua ſanguis emi • itur. & hieme, ſiniſtra.

p.hi: In the Sommer and Spring let bloud on the right ſide, and
in Autumne and Winter on the left.

div.p: In materia venenoſa debet fieri phlebotomia ex eademMateria venoſa. parte.

p.hi: In venimous matter let bloud on the ſame ſide.

div.p: Qui annos 60 habent, cephalicam non aperiant.Qui annos 60 habent.
At threeſcore yéeres let not bloud in cephalica.
Qui ſenes ſunt & aegroti edant iuſcula & bibant vinumSenes & aegroti. bonum vna vel altera hora ante ſectionem.

p.hi: Olde men and ſicke perſons may eate broth and drinke Wine one houre or two before they be let bloud.

div.p: Qui facile ac ſaepe ſudant, indigent venae ſectione.Qui phlebotomia indigent. Sectio conin • ta.

p.hi: They that ſweate eaſely and often neede bloudletting.

div.p: Sectio conſueta non ſine periculo praetermittitur.

p.hi: Accuſtomed bloudletting may not bee let paſſe without daunger.

div.p: A ſectione cibo vtere bono, ac tenui, vino ſubtili, vitansPoſt ſectionem. aquam mulſam, ceruiſiam, piſces & quae generant malum ſanguinem.

p.hi: After bloudletting vſe good meate, thinne diet, thinne wine, eſchew Honiedwater, Ale, Fiſh, and thoſe things which engender euill bloud.

div.p: Sectio venarum nō vrgente neceſsitate obeſt potius quam prodeſt.

p.hi: Bloud letten without neede vrging thereunto, doth more hurt then good.

div.head: De Ʋariolis.
div.p: SI variolae fuerint paucae & cito apparentes & quod citoVariolae paucae. maturentur ſigna ſunt bonae criſis.

p.hi: If the meaſels be fewe in quantitie, ſoone appearing, and that they be ſoone ripened, are ſignes of a good criſis.

div.p: Si vergant ad colorem violaceum, aut liuidum, aut viridemAd colorem violaccum, liuidum, viridem, aut nigrū vergentes. aut nigrum, omnes peſsimae & mortales.

p.hi: If they turne to bee blew, or ſwartiſh, or greene, or blacke colour,
they are very euill and deadly.

div.p: Si autem appareat ſanies foetida mortale.Sanies foetida.

p.hi: But if ſtinking matter do appeare, it is deadly.

div.head: De vulneribus generalis clocutio.
div.p: OMnis ſolutio facta in membro bonae complexionis, deMembri complexio. facili curatur, ſed cum eſt in corpore male complexionato de difficili curatur.

p.hi: Euery wound that is made in a member of good complexion is eaſely cured, but when it is in an euill complexioned bodie, it is hardly cured.

div.p: Vulnera membrorum radicalium cum deperditione ſubſtantiaeVulnera mē brorum radicalium. nunquam perfectè reſtaurantur, ſed ſine deperditione ſubſtantiae bene poſſunt vniri in pueritia, in alijs aetatibus verò non, ſed fit porus in circuitu.

p.hi: Wounds in the radicall members with loſſe of ſubſtance, are neuer perfectly reſtored: but if they be without loſſe of ſubſtance, they may well bee vnited in youth, and not in other ages: but that there remaineth a certaine concrete ſubſtance in the place.

div.p: Omne vulnus tranſiens à ſuperficie in ſuperficiem eſt malum,Vulnus tranſiens à ſuperficie ad ſuperficiem. quia natura non inuenit radicem vnde ſumat principium.

p.hi: Euery wound going from one ſuperficially part to another is euill, becauſe nature hath not found out a roote from whēce ſhe might take her beginning, of healing.

div.p: Si in vulneribus propter nimium fluxum venerit alienatio,A •• enatio. Spaſmus. Syncope. eſt malum, & ſi ſpaſmus vt plurimum moriuntur; & ſi ſyncope cum ſingultu mors eſt in ianuis.

p.hi: If in wounds, by reaſon of ouermuch fluxe of bloud, there chaunce alienation of the minde, it is euill; and if a cramp happen, for the moſt part they dye; but if there come ſownding, with yeſking, death is at the doore.

div.p:
Vulnera periculo non vacant dum poſt ſeptimum diem.
•• ando periculo vacant.

p.hi: Wounds are not paſt danger vntill after the ſeauenth day.

div.p: Vulnera a dolore & ſymptomate non aſſerta ſunt, donecQuando a dolore & ſymptomate aſſerta ſunt. pus concoquitur.

p.hi: Woundes are not voyde of greefe and accidents, vntill the matter be digeſted.

div.p: Vulneribus magnis tumor non apparens malum.Tumoria vulneribus magnis. Vulnera maligna.

p.hi: No ſwelling appearing in great woundes, is very euill.

div.p: Vulnera ſunt maligna ſi ſunt vndiquaque glabra.

p.hi: Thoſe wounds are maligne where the heare falleth off round about.

div.p: Vulneribus accidit febris die tertio, vel ſeptimo, aut non.Febris quand • accidit.

p.hi: To woundes chanceth a Feuer in the third or ſeauenth day, or not at all.

div.p: Sanguis in vulneribus congelatus celerimè rèmoueri ooportet,Sanguis congelata. ne dolor aut putrefactio inſequatur.

p.hi: Bloud that is congealed in woundes muſt be remoued with ſpeede, for feare of paine and putrefaction.

div.p: Vulnera in partibus ijs quae aſsiduo motu aguntur, raròIn partibus ijs quae aſsiduo motu aguntur. aut nunquam curantur.

p.hi: Woundes in thoſe parts which are without reſt, will hardly or neuer receiue curation.

div.p: Vulneribus quae incidunt in finibus muſculorum maiusIn finibus muſculorum. imminet periculum quam quibus in medio.

p.hi: Woundes in the endes of the muſcles, are more dangerous, then in the middeſt.

div.p: Quae in medio muſculorum contingunt optimè curātur.In medio muſculorum.

p.hi: Wounds in the middeſt of the muſcles are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Vulnera ſymptomatum expertia paruo nixu curantur.Abſque ſymptomatibus.

p.hi: Woundes voyde of accidents, are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Vulnus ad os vſque penetrans, oſsis ſanationem primumOſsis vulnus▪ petit, ante carnem regenerare cupias.

p.hi: A wounde in the bone requireth the healing thereof before incarnation of the fleſhe.

div.p: Vulnera oſsium, neruorum, cartilaginum, tendinum,Oſsium, neruorum, cartilaginum, tendinum, panniculorum, venarum, atque arteriarum vi laus. Carnis vulnera. panniculorum, venarum atque arteriarum ſecundum primam intentionem reſtitui ne expectes quidem.

p.hi: Woundes in the bones, ſinewes, griſtles, tendons, pannicles, veynes, and arteries, may not be looked for to be reſtored according to the firſt intention.

div.p: Vulnera carnis prima intentione reſtitui poſſunt.

p.hi: Woundes in the fleſh may be reſtored by the way of the firſt intention.

div.p: Vulnus cum carnis diuiſione citius curatur quam cum ſubſtantiae deperditione.

p.hi: A wounde with diuiſion of fleſh onely is ſooner cured, then with loſſe of ſubſtance.

div.p: Vulneris principio patiens, tenui ordiendus eſt dieta,Vulneris principio. vſque ad diem ſeptimum, praeſertim ſi fuerit calidus plethoricus.

p.hi: In the beginning of a wounde, the Patient muſt be ordered with a thinne dyet, vntill the ſeauenth day, eſpecially if he haue a hote and full bodie.

div.p: Vulnera profunda & magna, neſuito, nam intro materiamProfunda & magna vulnera. corruptam & fortaſſe venenoſam includere periculum eſt.

p.hi: Stitch not great and déepe wounds, for that it is in danger to ſhut in the corrupt and peraduenture venemous matter.

div.p: Vulnus contuſum, concauum vel diſcratum, in oſſe apoſtema,Conſolidantia 〈◊〉 non ſunt adhibenda. punctura in neruo, minime conſolidari debent.

p.hi: A contuſed hollow wound of diſtempered, an impoſtume in the bone, and a prick in the ſinewe, muſt be kept open.

div.p: Vulnus lethale eſt, acceptum in cerebro, corde, pulmone,Vulnera lethalia. diaphragmate, ventriculo, iecore, veſica & tenuibus inteſtinis.

p.hi: A wounde is deadly in the brayne, hart, lungs, midriffe, ſtomacke, liuer, bladder, and ſmall guttes.

div.p:
Vulnera capitis, & ſtomachi & hepatis, aut ſplenis autVulnera quae ſi parua ſint curari poſſunt.
renum, aut veſicae, aut matricis, aut inteſtinorum, ſiſi magna nunquam aut raro. ſint parua poſſunt curari, ſin magna, nunquā aut raro.

p.hi: Wounds in the head, ſtomack, liuer, ſplene, kidneies, bladder, matrice, or intrels, if they be ſmall may be cured, if they be great, they will hardly or neuer be cured.

div.p: Cerebri vulnera, ſcotoniam, lethargiam, apoplexiam &Cerebri vulnera. tales affectus proferunt.

p.hi: Woundes in the brayne bring giddineſſe, lethargies, apoplexies, and ſuch like diſeaſes.

div.p: Si cerebrum vulneretur, ſanies eſt craſſa, globoſa, & medullaris:Signa cerebri vulnera •• . ſpumaque ex ore, vertigo, ſpaſmus, febris, vomitus bilis, ſtupor & deſipientia ſequuntur.

p.hi: If the brayne be wounded, the matter is thicke, round, and mareylike: and foming at the mouth, giddineſſe, cramps, feuers, vomiting of choller, aſtoniſhment, and dotage do follow.

div.p: Cum cerebrum vehementer concutitur, vox amittitur.

p.hi: When the braine is ſore ſhaken, ſpeach is taken away.

div.p: Cerebro corrupto mors poſt triduum ſequitur.

p.hi: The braine being corrupted, death followeth within thrée dayes.

div.p: Vulnera capitis, cranio valente vel haud multum diminuto,Capitis vulnera cranio valente. curatu ſunt facilia.

p.hi: Woundes in the head where cranium is ſound or not much diminiſhed, are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Nigrities in partibus vulneri adiacentibus, conuulſioSigna mala. paraliſis, ciborum abſtinentia corporiſque frigiditas, praeſagiunt malum & paene inſanabile.

p.hi: Blacknes in the parts neare vnto the wound, the crampe, palſey, eſchewing of meate, and vniuerſall coldneſſe of the whole body, are euill ſignes, and almoſt vncurable.

div.p: Concoctio bona, vulneris rubedo, oſsis albedo, cumSigna bona. humiditatis repletione in partibus adiacentibus & ciborum appetitus, bonum ac ſanabile prognoſticant.

p.hi: Good dgeſtion, redneſſe of the wound, whiteneſſe of the bone, with fulneſſe of moyſture about the partes adiacent, and appetite to meate, doth prognoſticate good, and healthfulneſſe to the wound.

div.p: Cum magnis capitis vulneribus non bonum eſt verſari in plenilunio.

p.hi: It is not good to be ouerbuſy with great woundes in the head in the full of the moone.

div.p: Amigdalae propter vaporoſum quendam effectum ijs inſitum,Amigdalae. vulneribus capitis ſunt nociuae.

p.hi: Almonds are hurtfull for woundes in the head, by reaſon of a certayne fu •• oſity in them naturally contayned.

div.p: Vinum vulneribus capitis vel neruoſis niſi imminet magnaVinum. debilitas, malum.

p.hi: Wine is naught for wounds in the head and ſinewes, except there be great weakeneſſe.

div.p: In carnoſis faciei partibus vulnera facilimè curantur.Faciei vulnera.

p.hi: Woundes in the fleſhy parts of the face are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Oculorum vulnera ſunt periculoſa tum propter ipſumOculorum vulnera. viſum tum propter cerebri vicinitatem; caeterum ſi effundantur humores, ſequitur deſtructio oculi.

p.hi: Woundes in the eyes are dangerous both in reſpect of the ſight, and alſo of the vicinitie of the brayne, but if the humors do runne out, then followeth deſtruction of the eye.

div.p: Oculi rubei, etiam inflati, internam capitis laeſionemSigna partium internarum laeſionis. ſignificant: quod ſi bilis, primo, vel ſecundo, vel tertio die, vel deinceps vomitio appareat, laeſionem internarum partium ſignificat, non cerebri, ſed meningum.

p.hi: If the eyes be red and ſwollen, it ſignifieth the inward parts of the head to be hurt: not the brayne, but dura mater is hurt, if choller in the firſt, ſecond, or third day, or afterward be vomited.

div.p: Vulnera oculorum febres, apoſtemata, & lippitudinesOculorum vulnera. adferunt.

p.hi: Woundes in the eyes bring Feuers, Impoſtumes, and blearedues.

div.p: Aurium vulnera lethargiam & fiſtulas perducunt.Auriū vulnera.

p.hi: Woundes in the eares bring forgetfulnes and fiſtulaes.

div.p: Colli vulnera periculo non vacant: is enim locus eſt maiorum neruorum.

p.hi: Wounds in the necke are not free from daunger, becauſe it is the place of great ſinewes.

div.p: Colli vulnera magis ambigui ſunt quàm faciei.Colli vulnera.

p.hi: Wounds of the necke are more doubtfull than thoſe of the face.

div.p: Si neruus in collo incidatur motus perit.

p.hi: If a ſinewe in the necke be cut, ſome motion periſheth.

div.p:
Vulnera in ſcapulis periculoſa ſunt reſpectu neruorum abIn ſcapulis vulnera. nucha, & brachij iuncturarum, muſculorúm
que .

p.hi: Wounds in the ſhoulderblades are daungerous, by reaſon of the ſinewes comming from the backe, and by reaſon of the ioynts and muſcles of the arme.

div.p: Vulnera magna in ſcapulis adferunt febres, ſpaſmum, paraliſim, apoſtemata cum immenſo humorum influxu.

p.hi: Great woundes vppon the ſhoulderblades bring Feuers, Crampes, Palſies, Impoſtumes, with great inflowing of humors.

div.p: Dorſi vulnera ſpaſmos, febres, & mentis perturbationesDorſi vulnera. gignunt.

p.hi: Wounds in the backe bone bringeth Cramps, Feuers, and perturbation of the minde.

div.p: Vulnus ad ſpinalem medullam pertingens mortale & incurabile;Ad ſpinalem medullam pertingens vulnus. ſi verò non perueniat ad medullam, licet ſit curabile, timendum tamen eſt proper laeſionem neruorum orientium ab illa parte nuchae; & propter nocumentum ſenſus, & motus eorum membrorum, ad quae iſti nerui delegantur.

p.hi: A wound in the ſpinall marrowe is deadly and vncurable; but

if it come not to the marrowe, although it be curable, yet it is to bee feared, for hurting of the ſinewes, ſpringing from that part of the backe: and ſo for hurting the ſence and motion of the members whereinto theſe ſinewes are ſent.

div.p: Vulnera pulmonum, pthiſim, peripneumoniam & fiſtulasPulmonum. procreant.

p.hi: Woundes in the Lungs bring conſumption and inflammation of the Lungs, and fiſtulaes.

div.p: Pulmones eſſe vulneratas indicia haec ſunt: ſanguis rubicundusSigna pulmones vulneratas eſſe. eſt ſpumoſus, ſputum cruentum ſpumoſum, tuſsis, rumor in gutture, breuis anhelitus, praeſertim ſi vox pereat, aut cum ſono ſpiritus reddatur, & ſi inclinans in vulnus aeger loquatur, & in aliam partem obmuteſcat.

p.hi: The ſignes that the Lungs be wounded are theſe, viz. red and frothie bloud, bloudie and frothie ſpittle, a cough, noyſe in the throte, ſhort breath; eſpecially if the voyce doe fayle, or the breath be deliuered with ratling, alſo if bending toward the wound the patient ſpeake, but bending himſelfe otherwiſe cannot ſpeake.

div.p: Diaphragmatis vulnera ſpaſmos, anhelitus difficultatem,Diaphragmatis vulnera. & acutas febres perducunt.

p.hi: Wounds in the midriffe bring Cramps, ſtraightnes of breath and ſharpe Feuers.

div.p: Signa diaphragmatis vulnerati, ſunt, ſpiratio magna &Signa diaphragmatis vulnerati. frequens, tuſsis cum ſternutatione, alienatio, ſputum liuidum, ſitis, cibi faſtidium, rigor, & vulnus circa nothas coſtas.

p.hi: The ſignes that Diaphragma is wounded are theſe, great and thicke breathing, a cough with ſnorting, alienation of the minde, ſwartiſh ſpittle, thirſt, loathing of meate, ſtifnes, and the wound being about the falſe ribbes.

div.p: Hepatis vulnera inflammationes, apoſtemata, & ſanguineosHepatis vulnera. eoſque continuos fluxus perducunt.

p.hi: Woundes in the Liuer bring inflammations, Impoſtumes
and continuall fluxes of bloud.

div.p:
Si in parte dextra & prope nothas coſtas vulnus ſit & multusSigna hae ••
tis laeſ • . ſanguis perfluit craſſus, iecur laeſum eſſe conijcimus.

p.hi: If the wound be in the right ſide and nere vnto the falſe ribbes and that great quantitie of thick bloud iſſue out, we coniecture the Liuer to be hurt.

div.p: Pectoris vulnera non intus penetrantia facilè curantur; &Pectoris vulnera. è contrario contrariè.

p.hi: Wounds of the breaſt not pearcing into the bulke, are caſie of curation: and contrariwiſe contrarily.

div.p: Cordis vulnera lethalia ſunt, quia eſt effector vitalis ſpiritusCordis vulnera. & fons arteriarum.

p.hi: Woundes in the heart are deadly, becauſe it is the maker of vitall ſpirites, and originall of arteries.

div.p: Corvulneratum eſſe indicia haec ſunto; ſanguis niger effluens,Signa cordis vulnerati. extremorum frigiditas, ſudores frigidi, ſyncope, color pallidus ac totae vires debilitatae.

p.hi: The ſignes that the heart is wounded are theſe, blacke bloud flowing out of the wound, coldneſſe of the outward parts, colde ſweats, ſownding, pale colour, and the whole ſtrength decayed.
