div.p: In inteſtinis magnis ob externas eorum carnoſitates vulneraInteſtinorum vulnera. ſanabilia videntur: exiguis autem longe periculoſiora ac dolorum pleniora, propter ſubſtantiam eorum neruoſam.

p.hi: Wounds in ye great guttes by reaſon of their outward fleſhines are eaſie to bee cured: but farre more daungerous are woundes in the ſmall guttes, and more paynfull; becauſe they are of ſinewie ſubſtance.

div.p: Vulnera renum, ſpaſmum, alienationem animi, & mortemRenum vulnera. inferunt.

p.hi: Woundes in the Kidneis bring the Crampe, perturbation of the minde and death.

div.p: Veſicae vulnus adfert ſpaſmum, vrinae fluxum continuumVulnera veſicae mortemque.

p.hi: Wounds in the bladder bring the Crampe, continuall fluxe of vrine and deat • .

div.p: Omne vulnus prope circiterue iuncturam vllam, muſculiIuncturarum vulnus actionem membri depriuat. alicuius originem aut inſertionem ſeparet neceſſe eſt. Muſculus eſt inſtrumentum motus voluntarij, ergo omne vulnus inſtrumenta motus voluntarij ſupprimens, actionem membri ſequentis depriuare oportet.

p.hi: Euery wound that is made neere or about any ioynt doth of neceſſitie ſeparate either the riſing or inſertion of ſome muſcle. A muſcle is the inſtrument of voluntarie mouing: Therefore euery wound that ſuppreſſeth the inſtruments of voluntarie mouing muſt needes depriue the action of the member following.

div.p: Iuncturarum vulnera periculoſa, quoniam neruis, tendonibus,Iuncturarum vulnera quare periculoſa ſunt. & ligamentis vinciuntur, membraniſque veſtiuntur.

p.hi: Woundes in the ioynts bee daungerous, becauſe they bee enwrapped with Sinewes, Tendons, Ligaments and Pannicles.

div.p: Iuncturarum vulnera ſequuntur febres, ſpaſmi, & membri deprauatio.

p.hi: Upon woundes in the ioynts followe Feuers, Cramps and deprauation of the member.

div.p: Vulnera iuncturarum cum neruorum ac tendinum diſſectioneVtrum neruus vel tendo diſſectus ſit cognolcere. eſſe ſolent, quare ſi ſtatim aeger totum manum aut maiotem partem manus, ſtupidam, grauem, frigidam ſenſerit, neruum laeſum eſſe veriſimile eſt; quod ſi ſine magna inflatione ſit, & neque flectere neque extendere poſsit, tendo illius partis diſſectus eſt.

p.hi: Wounds in the ioynts doe chaunce with the cutting of the ſinewes and tendons: wherefore if the partie feele his whole hand or a great part thereof to be without ſence, heauie and colde, it is a true ſigne that the ſinewe is hurt: but if the
hand be without any great ſwelling, and yet can neyther be bowed, nor extended, then is the tendon of that part cut.

div.p: Fibrarum tranſuerſa diuiſio muſculi officium impedit.Fibrarum vulnus.

p.hi: Ouerthwart cutting of the fibres impaireth the office of the muſcle.

div.p: Solutio continuitatis in neruo ſi eſt inciſio aut punctura,Neruorum vulnera. ſpaſmum & alienationem, & mortem inducit, niſi diligenti • simè ſuccurratur, & ſi omnino incidatur, nō eſt periculum, niſi quia membrum ſuppoſitum caret motu aut ſenſu, aut vtroque, ſecundum diuerſitatem neruorum.

p.hi: A wound in the ſinew eyther by inciſion or pricking, bringeth a crampe, alienation of the minde and death, if it be not diligently helped; but if it be cleane cut aſunder, it is no danger at all, ſaue onely that the member is depriued of mouing or feeling, or both, according to the diuerſities of ſinewes.

div.p: Vulnus ad neruos recurrentes pertingens, rancedinemAd neruos recurrdntes vulnus pertingens. inducit.

p.hi: A wounde in the recurrent nerues bringeth hoarſeneſſe.

div.p: Vulnera ſecundum longitudinem neruorum, non tamVulnus neruorum ſecundum longitudinem. periculoſa ſunt, quàm ſi tranſuerſim diuidantur.

p.hi: Woundes that are made after the length of the ſinewes, are not ſo dangerous, as when they are cut ouerthwart.

div.p: Laeſio neruorum per contuſionem, magis periculoſa, quā Neruorum contuſio. per inciſionem, quia non tam facile digeſtio inducitur.

p.hi: Hurt of ſinewes that commeth by contuſion, is more dangerous then by meiſion, by reaſon that digeſtion can not be ſo ſoone brought to paſſe.

div.p: Vulnera neruorum per deſiccantia curantur.Curatio.

p.hi: Woundes in the ſinewes are cured by deſiccatiue medicines.

div.p: Vulnera neruorum per contuſionem digerentibus curantur.Curatio.

p.hi: Woundes in the ſinewes made by contuſion, are to be helped
by diſperſing medicines.

div.p: Punctio neruorum, inciſione periculoſior.Punctio neruorum.

p.hi: Woundes in the ſinewes made by pricking weapons, are more dangerous than by inciſion.

div.p: Vulnera neruorum ſi humores collectos expirare non valent, in periculo apoſtematum ſpaſmique ſunt.

p.hi: Woundes in the ſinewes that cannot breathe out the humors collected, are in danger of impoſtumes and Cramps.

div.p: Neruorum vulnus ſi in ſuperiori parte corporis inciderit,Neruorum in ſuperiori parte vulnus. iuncturas colli, pectuſque cum iuncturis adiacentibus vnge.

p.hi: If the ſinewes in the vpper parts be wounded, it is good to anoynt the vertebres of the necke, and the breſt, with the ioynts about the wounded part.

div.p: Si autem in inferiori parte euenit, lumborum vertebrae,In inferiori parte neruorum vulnus. os ſacrum, inguen, iuncturae, parteſque adiacentes inungantur.
But if the wounde of the ſinewes chance in the nether parts, anoynt the vertebres of the loyues, os ſacrum, flancks, ioynts, and other parts adiacent.
Euaporantia vulneribus neruorum magis conueniuntMedicamenta vulneribus neruorum conuenientiſſima. quam repercutientia.

p.hi: Euaporatiue medicines are more conuenient for wounds in the ſinewes, then repercuſſiues.

div.p: Principio vulnerum neruorum nec conglutinantia, nec incarnantia expediunt, donec omni periculo vacant.

p.hi: Woundes in the ſinewes at the beginning require neyther conglutinatiues, nor incarnatiues, vntill they be paſt all danger.

div.p: Si in punctione neruorum venerit apoſtematio nocent deſiccantia, reſoluentia tamen, & mollificantia, cum attractione familiari maximè conueniunt.

p.hi: If in pricking of ſinewes there happen impoſtumation, deſiccative medicines are hurtfull, but reſolutiues, and mollificatiues,
with familiar attraction, are moſt conuenient.

div.p: Mollificantia & maturantia in omni punctione neruorum periculoſa ſunt.

p.hi: Mollificatiue and maturatiue medicines are dangerous in all pricks of the ſinewes.

div.p: Medicamina neruis vulneratis adhibita ſubtilia & liquida cum attractione familiari eſſe debent, non ſolum vt virtus eorum celeriter ad partem affectam adueniat, verum etiā vt materiam cōtentam ſine dolore trahat.

p.hi: Medicines applyed to wounded ſinewes, muſt be ſubtill and liquid with familiar attraction, not onely that their vertue may more ſpéedely come to the affected part, but alſo, that they may drawe without payne the matter fixed in the greeued part.

div.p: Medicamina neruis vulneratis actu calide applicentur.

p.hi: Medicines applied to wounded ſinewes, ought to be actually hote.

div.p: Nerui tendineſque per vulnera nudati, celerrime carni amiciri debent, cum medicamentis temperaturae bonae potius calidis quam frigidis.

p.hi: Sinewes and tendons lying bare by woundes, ought ſpeedily to be couered with fleſh, by medicines of good temperature, and rather hote then cold.

div.p: Nerui iuuenibus ſunt ſine periculo ſuendi, adultis nonNerui iuuenum ſuendi ſunt. item.

p.hi: Young mens ſinewes may be ſtitched without danger, but in old perſons not ſo.

div.p: Si in oſſe ſit vulnus tendineſque digitorum exteriores ſecantur,In oſſe vulnus. digiti tamen poſtquam extendi poſſunt.

p.hi: If there be a wound in the bone, and the exterior tendons of the fingers be cut, yet the fingers may after wards be extended.

div.p: Si os ſit vulneratum interiori parte digitorum vbi tendines diuidantur, nunquam digiti poſtquam extendi queant.

p.hi: If the bone be wounded in the inſide of the fingers where the tendons are diuided, the fingers neuer after can be ſtretched foorth.

div.p: Partes omnes ex ſanguine generatae reſtaurationem citò admittunt.

p.hi: Thoſe parts that are engendred of bloud, are ſoone reſtored.

div.p: Flegmatici & melancholici carnes comedant & vinumFlegmatici & melancholici vulnerati. bibant initio vulneris.

p.hi: Flegmatike and melancholick perſons may eate fleſh, and drinke wine in the beginning of a wound.

div.p: Ruſticis quàm delicatis vulnera citius curantur.

p.hi: Woundes in ſtrong and ruſticall bodies, are ſooner cured, than in tender bodies.

div.p: Sagitta vel globulus venenatus per ingentem dolorem,Sagitta vel globulo venenato. tumorem & nigredinem cognoſcuntur.

p.hi: Arrowes & bullets that are venemous are knowne by great payne, ſwelling, & blackneſſe that follow in their wounds.

div.head: De Vlceribus.
div.p: ANi vlcera concaua, aetate confecta, aegrè vel nunquamAni vlcera. curantur.

p.hi: Hollow vlcers in the fundament in an aged partie, are hardly or neuer cuted.

div.p: Vlcera in corpore hydropico, leproſo & rheumatico peraegrèIn corpore hydropico vlcera. vel nunquam curantur.

p.hi: Ulcers in a dropſey, leprous, and rheumatike body, are hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: Cruribus antiquata vlcera cum ſimul contracta duritieIn carnibus vlcera. difficilis ſunt curationis.

p.hi: Ulcers in the legs of continuance, with hardneſſe about the affected part, are hard of curation.

div.p: Capitis vlcera nunc di • nata aegrè curantur.Capitis vlcera.

p.hi: Ulcers in the head, of continuance, are hard to be cured.

div.p: Capitis vlcera ſerpentia difficilè emendantur.

p.hi: Créeping vlcers in the head are hard to be cured.

div.p: Vlcera in corpore humorum corruptela referto aegrè curantur.In corpore conupta vlcera.

p.hi: Ulcers in a body full of corrupt humors are hard of curation.

div.p: Vlcera in corporibus teneris facile curantur.In corporibus teneris vlcera.

p.hi: Ulcers in young bodies are eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Corporibus macilentis quàm in obeſis vlcera facilius curantur.In corperibus macilentis vlcera.

p.hi: Ulcers in leane bodies be eaſier to be cured then in thoſe that be fat.

div.p: Materia caerulei vel liuidi coloris difficultatem curationisMateria caerulei vel liuidi coloris. planè comminatur.

p.hi: Matter that is blew or ſwartiſh in colour, doth playnely declare difficultie of curation.

div.p: Materia citrina lixiuio abſimilis, parit in vicinis partibusMateria citrina. eroſiones, & curationis difficultatem.

p.hi: Yellow matter like vnto lée, bringeth eroſions to the partes round about, and hardneſſe of curation.

div.p: Pus groſſum & in fundo hoerens prius abſtergendum antèPus groſſum. aggrediatur cura.

p.hi: Groſſe matter cleauing to the bottome, ought firſt to be clenſed, before healing be gone in hand withall.

div.p: Pus ſi ſit album & craſſum, bonum, ſi ſubcruentum & foetidum,Pus album & craſſum ſubcruentum & foetidum. malum.

p.hi: If the matter be white, it is good, but if it be bloudy and ſtiucking, it is euill.

div.p: Oſsis ſcalprata caries, vlcus tunc, & non ante ſanabitur.Oſsis caries.

p.hi: The putrefaction of the bone being taken away, the vlcer will then be cured, but not before.

div.p: Caro nigra in oſſe aegrotante, malum.Caro nigra.

p.hi: Blacke fleſh when the bone is craſy, is euill.

div.p:
Corpore phlegmatico vlcera albeſcunt, ſic ſanies groſſa,In corpore phlegmatico vlcera.
viſcoſa & ſubalbida.

p.hi: Ulcers in a phlegmatike body are white, and the Matter is groſſe, flymy and whitiſh.

div.p:
Corpus calidum & ſiccum, erit vlcus rubrum in circuituCorporibus calidis & ſic
•• s • l • era. non abſque dolore & inflamatione, preterquam quod color materiae ad citrinitatem, rubedinem, flauitatem vel viriditatem tender.

p.hi: Ulcers in a hote and dry body, wil be red in the Circuite, not without payne and inflamation; and beſides that, the colour of the Matter will be citrine, red, yellow, or gréene.

div.p: Melancholici habent vlcera fuſci coloris, corpus macerumMelancholicis vlcera. & exiccatum, tum ſanies nigreſcens, denſa, inſtar cineris & coeni miſtionis.

p.hi: Melancholick perſons haue vlcers black in colour, a leane and dry body, and the Matter is thick waxing black, like vnto the mixing of aſhes and dirt.

div.p: Membro in affecto ſanguis non debitam habens proportionem,Sanguis debitam non habens proportionem. curationem impedit, ſi maximè redundat, naturalem prorſus ſuffocabit calorem, & ad membrum ſolitos acceſſus nutrimenti prohibebit.

p.hi: In the affected member, if the bloud haue not his due proportion, it doth hinder the cure; if it do greatly abounde, it will altogether ſuffocate naturall heate, and prohibite the wonted comming thereto of nouriſhment.

div.p: Cauernoſa inguinis vlcera aegrèvel nunquam curantur.Inguinis vlcera. Iuncturarum vlcera.

p.hi: Hallow vlcers in the flancke are hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: Vlcera in iuncturis perdurantia, nunquam ſine oſsis vel iuncturae iactura curantur.

p.hi: Ulcers in the ioynts of continuance are neuer cured without the ieopardie of ſome bone or ioynt.

div.p: Omnis humorum acuitas vlcera pruritu affligit.Humorum acuitas.

p.hi: All ſharpneſſe of humors afflicteth vlcers with • ching.

div.p: Vlcera in collo veſicae ſi diutius permanſerint aegerrimèIn collo veſicae vlcus. aut nunquam curantur.

p.hi: Ulcers in the neck of the bladder of long continuance, are hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: Vlcera ad medullam vſque putreſcentia difficulter autAd medullam vlcera putreſcentia. nunquam curantur.

p.hi: Ulcers that putrefie to the marrow of the bone, are hardly or neuer cured.

div.p: Vlcera in extrema parte manuum ac pedum inueterata,Manuum aut pedum vl. era. difficilis ſunt curationis.

p.hi: Ulcers that be of any continuance eyther in the back of the hand, or top of the foote, are hard of curation.

div.p: In naſo vlcera rarò abſque incommodo curantur.In • aſo 〈…〉

p.hi: Ulcers in the noſe are ſeldome cured without a diſcōmoditie.

div.p: In naribus vlcera, os vel cartilaginem penetrantia, aegrèIn 〈…〉 vlcera curantur.

p.hi: Ulcers in the noſtrils pearcing either the bone or griſtle, are hard to be cured.

div.p:
Vlcera neruis vicinantia ſaepenumero ſpaſmum inducūt.Neruis vi ••
nantia.

p.hi: Ulcers yt are néere ye ſinewes, do oftentimes bring ye crampe.

div.p: Sanies foetida mala eſt & ſignum corruptionis quae maturationiSanies • oetida contraria eſt, indicatque aegrotum caliditatis naturalis eſſe deſtitutum.

p.hi: Stinking Matter is euill, and a ſigne of putrefaction, which is contrary to ripening, and ſheweth the patient to be deſtitute of naturall heate.

div.p: Ex humorib, calidis cū aquoſitate & ebullitione fit virus.Virus.
Virus is made of hote humors, with watriſhnes and boyling.
Sordes vero ex ſuperfluitate humorum frigidorum &Sordes. groſsitie eorum.

p.hi: Filthy matter is engendred by the ſuperflui • ie and groſſenes of cold humors.

div.p: Vlcera ſubitò exicantia & citra cauſam manifeſtam, malum,Vlcera ſubitō exiccantia. atque nigreſcentia mortem adferunt.

p.hi: Ulcers drying vp ſodainely without any manifeſt cauſe, ſignify euill, and if they waxe blacke, it is a ſigne of death.

div.p: Iniectiones fiſtuloſis vlceribus conuenientes mediocriterFiſtuloſis vlceribus iniectiones conuenientes. deſiccare debent.

p.hi: Iniectiōs agréeing to fiſtulated vlcers, ought to dry meanely.

div.p: Vlceribus ſufficienter mundificatis, erit ſanies pulchra &Vlcera ſufficienter mundificata. alba ſine omni faetore.

p.hi: In vlcers ſufficiently cleanſed, there will be faire and white Matter, without ſtincke.

div.p: Qui habent vlcera concaua, cibis magni nutrimenti veſcantur,Vlcera concaua. vt bonum ſanguinem generent.

p.hi: Let them that haue hollow vlcers, eate meate of great nourtſhment to engender good bloud.

div.p: Vertebrae ſi corrumpuntur, fuge curam.Vertebrarum corruptio.

p.hi: If the vertebres growe defiled, ſh • m medling with the cure.

div.p: Vlcus varicoſum tam cum vlceratione, quàm ſine vlcerationeVlcus varicoſum. confirmatum, non ſine periculo curatur.

p.hi: A various vlcer, whether with vlceration, or without vlceration, being once confirmed, can not be cured without danger.

div.p: Cura paliatiua in vlcere varicoſo maxime prodeſt: namCura paliatiua maximè prodeſt. meatus innaturalis, quò diutius aliquid è corpore emanare conſueuit, obturari non poteſt, ſine timore.

p.hi: In a various vlcer, a paliatiue cure is moſt conuenient: for an vnnaturall iſſue, whereby nature is wo • t long time to emptie from the bodie, can not be ſtopped without danger.

div.p: Curatio varicum non vlceratorum, per inciſiouem non ſine ingenti periculo efficitur, propter ſluxum ſanguinis inde promanantem.

p.hi: To cure ſwollen veynes not vlcerated, by inciſion, is verie dangerous, by reaſon of the fluxe of bloud which wil enſue.

div.p: Varices optimè curantur per fontanellam cum rupturioVaricum curatio optima. vel igne ſub genu per quatuor digitos, in parte exteriori, qua materia purgetur.

p.hi: The beſt way to cure ſwollen veynes, is to make an iſſue eyther
with an actuall or potentiall camery, foure fingers vnder the outſide of the knée, whereby the matter may be purged out.

div.head: Vtrum vlcus ſit facilis vel difficilis curationis quatuordecini conditiones.
div.p: PRima eſt ſigura vlceris, nam vlcus rotundum difficulter1. Figura vlceris. curatur, longum vero faciliter.

p.hi: The firſt is the figure of the vlcer, for a round vlcer is hard to be cured, but a long eaſy.

div.p: Secunda eſt ſimplicitas vel compoſitio: nam ſimplex vlcus2. Simplicitas vel compoſitio. faciliter curatur, compoſitum difficulter.

p.hi: The ſecond is the ſimplicitie or compoſition: for a ſimple vlcer is eaſy to be cured, but a compound, hard.

div.p: Tertia eſt cum deperditione partis membri organici vlcus,3. Deperditione partis membri organici. & tale difficulter curatur.

p.hi: The third is an vlcer with the loſſe of the part of the organick member, and ſuch a one is hard to be cured.

div.p: Quarta eſt vlcus cum duritie, & tale difficulter curatur.4. Vlcus cum du • itie.

p.hi: The fourth is an vlcer with hardneſſe, and that is hard to be cured.

div.p: Quinta eſt deperditio ſubſtantiae vel eius non deperditio,5. Deperditio ſubſtantiae. nam vlcus cum deperditione ſubſtantiae cum difficultate curatur.

p.hi: The fift is an vlcer with loſſe of ſubſtance, or which out loſſe of ſubſtance, for an vlcer with loſſe of ſubſtance, is hard to be cured.

div.p: Sexta quando vlcus eſt in membro exangui, tale enim6. Vlcus in membro exangui. difficulter curatur: contrarium accidit ſi membrum non ſit exangue.

p.hi: The ſixt is when the vlcer is in a member without bloud, and ſuch a one is hard to be cured, but if the member be endued with bloud, it is eaſy.

div.p: Septima eſt nobilitas membri aut eius ignobilitas: nam7. Membri nobilitas aut ignobilitas. fi vlcus in aliquo membro nobili ſit, eius curatio eſt difficilis aut impoſsibilis, ſecus autem accidit in membro ignobili.

p.hi: The ſeauenth is the nobility or ignobility of the member, for if ye vlcer be in any noble member, it is hard or vnpoſſible to be cured, but if it be in a baſe member it is eaſy to be cured.

div.p: Octaua eſt ſi vlcus fuerit in mēbro ſubtili vt in panniculis,8. In membro ſubtili vel groſſo. veſica, &c. tale enim difficulter curatur, ſi vero fuerit in mēbro groſſo faciliter, ſi in mediocri, mediocriter.

p.hi: The eight is if the vlcer be in a ſubtile member, as the pannicles, bladder, &c. and ſuch a one is hard to be cured, but if it be in a groſſe member it is eaſy, if in a meane member, meanely.

div.p: Nona eſt motus membri & ipſius quies, nam motus9. Membri motus & quies. membri vlcerati impoſsibilitatem & difficultatem facit, vt patet in pulmone, arterijs, & diaphragmate, quies vero facilitatem facit curationis.

p.hi: The ninth is the mouing and reſt of the member, for the mouing of the member maketh the cure hard and vnpoſſible, as it hapneth in the lungs, arteries, and midriffe, but reſt maketh the cure eaſy.

div.p: Decima eſt inceſſus ſuperfluitatum ſuper membrum vlceratum,10. Inceſſus ſuperfluitatum ſuper membrum vlceratum. nam earum inceſſus difficultatem operatur, vt patet in ventrieulo, inteſtinis, veſica, matrice, virga, &c.

p.hi: The tenth is the courſe of ſuperfluities vpon the vlcerated member, which cauſeth hardneſſe of curation, as it chanceth in ye ventricle, entrayles, bladder, matrice, yard, & ſuch like.

div.p: Vndecima eſt quando corpus eſt repletum multis ſuperfluitatibus,11. Corpus multis ſuperfluitatibus repletum. vt ſunt corpora cachochimica, in talibus enim vlcera ſunt difficilis curationis, contrarium accidit corporibus mundis.

p.hi: The xi. is when the body is repleniſhed with many ſuperfluities, as the bodies full of euill iuyce; for vlcers in ſuch bodies are hard of curation, but in cleane bodies contrary.

div.p: Duodecima eſt quando non poſſunt debitae vlceribus12. medicinae appropriari.

p.hi: The twelfth is when as due medicines can not be applied to the vlcers.

div.p: Decimatertia eſt ſitus membri in alta vel infima parte13. Situs membri. corporis, nam vlcera in membris ſuperioribus faciliter curantur, quae vero ſunt in inferioribus difficulter.

p.hi: The xiii. is the ſituation of the member in a high or lowe part of the body, for vlcers in the ſuperior members are eaſy to be cured, but in the inferior hard.

div.p: Decimaquarta eſt profundita 〈…〉 ceris, nam vlcus profundum14. Vlceris profunditas. cum difficultate curatur, non profundum verò faciliter.

p.hi: The xiiii. is the deapth of the vlcer, for a déepe vlcer is hard to be cured, but that that is not déepe, is eaſy to be cured.

div.p:
Vlcera virulentia ab humore bi • ioſo • aſ • untur, & ad acuitatem per pituitam ſalſam perueniunt, quibus inui
• em permixtis accidit aduſtio, & tun • virulentia.

p.hi: Ʋiculent vlcers proceede of a cholerick humor, and come to ſharpnes by reaſon of ſalt flegme, which mixing with the choller, cauſeth aduſtion, and then virulencie.

div.p: Sorditiei duae ſunt cauſae, propria & dependens, cauſa propria eſt quaedam in carne malignitas & vocatur proprietas occulta, cauſa dependens eſt humorum improborum eſſentia, carnem depaſcens & erodens cum ad coniunctam aduenit vt per bilem cum flegmate ſalſo permixtam.

p.hi: There be two cauſes of filthy Matter, as a proper, and a depending, the proper, is a certayne malignitie in the fleſh, which is called a hidden property: the cauſe depending, is euill humors, which eate or corrode the fleſh when they come to the coniunct, as by choller mixt with ſaite flegme.

div.p:
Varicum cauſae ſunt, lienis opilatio, hepatis imbecilitas,
ciborum melancholicorum nimius vſus, longa ſtatio, & onerum aggrauatio.

p.hi: The cauſes of varices are, ſtopping of the ſpléene, weakenes of the liuer, much vſe of melancholy meates, long ſtanding, and bearing of great burthens.

div.p: Vlcus cacoethes niſi valido remedio non cedit.
That kinde of vlcer called cacoethes, yéeldeth not but to a ſtrong and moſt forceable medicine.
